questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to diarrhea and abdominal cramps for the last 4 months. She has had on average 5 bowel movements daily. The stool is watery and contains mucus but no blood. She has also noticed that her cramps are relieved after each bowel movement. The patient has not experienced weight loss, fever, or change in appetite. Past medical history is significant for migraine headaches, for which she occasionally takes acetaminophen. The patient does not take any other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing, imaging, and colonoscopy results are normal. She is diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome and prescribed loperamide. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action in reducing diarrhea?

choices.text: Reduction of colonic peristalsis by inhibiting the release of excitatory neurotransmitters in the myenteric plexus
Inhibition of colonic migrating motor complex with resultant slowing of colonic contraction
Inhibition of cytokine release and reduction of colonic wall inflammation
Inhibition of muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles

questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal cramps and diarrhea. She is diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and started on loperamide.

Loperamide is an opioid agonist that exerts its antidiarrheal effects by binding to and activating μ-opiate receptors in the enteric nervous system. Activation of the μ-receptors in the colon inhibits the release of excitatory neurotransmitters (acetylcholine) from the myenteric nerve plexus, which in turn decreases peristalsis, slows colonic motility, and allows more water to be absorbed. Ultimately, loperamide reduces stool volume, increases viscosity, and diminishes fluid loss.

Loperamide is used to treat IBS-diarrhea and chemotherapy-associated diarrhea as well as decrease ileostomy output. It undergoes significant first-pass hepatic metabolism, resulting in very low plasma levels. Furthermore, loperamide has poor blood-brain barrier penetration and as a result, has negligible central nervous system manifestations and low potential for addiction or tolerance. It may cause mild cramps and, when taken in high doses, rebound constipation.

Diphenoxylate is another opioid agonist that is sometimes used to treat IBS diarrhea. At low doses, diphenoxylate does not cross the blood-brain barrier. However, it does at higher doses. To reduce the likelihood of abuse, it is frequently mixed with atropine, which exerts unpleasant anticholinergic symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes) when taken in higher amounts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reduction of colonic peristalsis by inhibiting the release of excitatory neurotransmitters in the myenteric plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of colonic migrating motor complex with resultant slowing of colonic contraction:
Incorrect: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil) are sometimes associated with constipation due to inhibition of colonic migrating motor complexes and slowing of colonic contraction.  
❌ Inhibition of cytokine release and reduction of colonic wall inflammation:
Incorrect: Steroids are used in inflammatory bowel diseases (e.g. ulcerative colitis) to reduce inflammation of the intestinal walls and decrease inflammatory cytokines release. Steroids have no role in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome since there is no underlying inflammation.  
❌ Inhibition of muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles:
Incorrect: Hyoscyamine and dicyclomine are antispasmodics that are used in patients with irritable bowel syndrome to relieve abdominal pain or discomfort. These anticholinergic drugs inhibit muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles.  
❌ Reduction of intestinal fluid secretion:
Incorrect: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is sometimes used to treat secretory diarrhea by reducing intestinal fluid secretion. It also inhibits the release of numerous hormones in the gastrointestinal tract and decreases gallbladder contraction.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with two days of sharp abdominal pain and vomiting. Past medical history includes bipolar disorder and pituitary microadenoma without laboratory abnormalities. His only medication is valproic acid. Past surgical history includes appendectomy, cholecystectomy, and inguinal hernia repair. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, there is diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation and hypoactive bowel sounds. There is no abdominal rigidity or guarding. Computed tomography of the abdomen reveals a high-grade small bowel obstruction without any intra-abdominal masses. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm with a QT interval of 420 ms. A nasogastric tube is placed and the patient is started on intravenous fluids. The patient requests an anti-nausea medication. Which of the following is a contraindication to metoclopramide use?
questions.solution:
This patient has small bowel obstruction, likely due to prior abdominal surgery. Bowel obstruction is a contraindication to metoclopramide therapy.      

Metoclopramide blocks dopamine receptors in the brain. Moreover, it facilitates muscarinic receptor-mediated gastric emptying and increases lower esophageal sphincter tone. It is commonly used for gastroparesis in patients with diabetes mellitus.    

Metoclopramide is contraindicated in patients with bowel obstruction since the medication promotes gastrointestinal motility and can worsen the symptoms of obstruction. The medication should be avoided in patients with Parkinson’s disease due to its anti-dopaminergic properties.    

Metoclopramide can precipitate tardive dyskinesia in patients on other anti-dopaminergic agents (e.g., haloperidol, aripiprazole) and thus concurrent administration should be done with caution. It can also elevate prolactin levels and should be avoided in patients with hyperprolactinemia. Finally, the medication can prolong the QT interval.

Option Analysis

❌ Pituitary microadenoma:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide can raise prolactin levels and should be avoided in patients with hyperprolactinemia. However, this patient has a clinically silent pituitary microadenoma, which implies that prolactin and other pituitary hormone levels are normal.
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide should be avoided in patients taking antipsychotics as the combined anti-dopaminergic effects can precipitate tardive dyskinesia. However, bipolar disorder itself is not a contraindication to metoclopramide, and valproic acid does not have significant effects on dopaminergic pathways.
❌ Presence of nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: The presence of a nasogastric tube is not a contraindication to promotility agents (e.g., erythromycin, metoclopramide).
✅ Small bowel obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ QT interval of 420 ms:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide should be used cautiously in patients with slight QT interval prolongation and avoided in patients with significant QT prolongation. Definitions of normal QT intervals vary slightly by source, but in general, less than 430-450 in males and less than 450-470 in females is considered within normal range.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and confusion for the past 24 hours. The pain is stabbing in character, worse in the upper abdomen, and is associated with nausea and non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows that the patient is oriented to the person but not to time and place. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is delayed. Skin and sclera are icteric. Abdominal examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric region without rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen is suggestive of an impacted gallstone. Which of the following is the most likely location of gallstone impaction due to this patient’s symptoms?  

 Laboratory features 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  150,000/mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Serum electrolytes  
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  106 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  17 mEq/L 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   2.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  65 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  30 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain (RUQ) (aka Charcot triad) most likely has ascending cholangitis, secondary to the gallstone impaction in the common bile duct (CBD). Confusion and hypotension (Reynold pentad) are also sometimes seen in severe cases.  

Gallstones can migrate from the gallbladder into the cystic duct where it can obstruct the bile outflow, causing biliary colic (intense, spasmodic pain located in the right hypochondrium) when the gallbladder contracts. The accumulation of bile can subsequently lead to the development of cholecystitis, which presents clinically as a positive Murphy’s sign, which is pain and discomfort on inspiration when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand in the RUQ.  

Gallstone impaction at the CBD can lead to bacterial invasion of bile from the intestinal flora. This can lead to the development of ascending cholangitis, characterized by Charcot triad. Additionally, when impacted in the main pancreatic duct, it can cause pancreatitis (e.g., anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain).  

Finally, an enlarged and inflamed gallbladder can develop communications with adjacent viscera (cholecystoenteric fistula), most commonly between the gallbladder and the duodenum. The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum. It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a complication of long-standing cholelithiasis where the gallstone forms a cholecystoenteric fistula between the gallbladder and the adjoint gut (duodenum). The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum (narrowest portion of the intestine). It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain/distention, nausea/vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal tenderness). This patient’s presentation is consistent with ascending cholangitis.  
✅ Common bile duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Main pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones can migrate from the common bile duct and obstruct the main pancreatic duct, leading to pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. Symptoms of pancreatitis include anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Serum lipase levels are usually elevated (unlike this patient). Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Cystic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones are usually located in the gallbladder but can migrate in the cystic duct, obstructing the bile’s way out of the gallbladder. When the gallbladder contracts, this further leads to biliary colic, which is an intense, spasmodic pain located in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) of the abdomen. The accumulation of bile can also lead to the inflammation and irritation of gallbladder (cholecystitis), presenting as Murphy’s sign (pain/tenderness in the RUQ sufficient to cause an abrupt halt in inspiration) on physical examination. Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The caliber of duodenum is typically sufficient to allow the passage of larger gallstones.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of weight gain and abdominal discomfort. The patient reports mild, diffuse abdominal discomfort for the past week and a weight gain of 10 lbs (4.5 kg) over the past month. She does not have nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient is a truck driver and has not seen a physician in years. She drinks a 6-pack of beer per night. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mmHg. Physical examination shows jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, a flapping hand tremor on wrist extension, and a positive fluid wave. The portal venous pressure is 5 mmHg greater than the inferior vena cava pressure. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following secondary to her current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with ascites, flapping hand tremor, and an elevated pressure in the portal venous system (as compared to systemic venous system) is suggestive of portal hypertension.  

Portal hypertension means increased pressure in the portal venous system. It develops when there is resistance to portal blood flow and is aggravated by increased portal collateral blood flow. It is most commonly caused by liver cirrhosis but can also be caused by vascular obstruction (e.g., portal vein thrombosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and schistosomiasis).  

Portal hypertension leads to the formation of portosystemic shunts, which is when blood is diverted away from the portal venous system and backs up into systemic veins at the sites called portal-systemic anastomoses/porto-caval anastomosis. These include: 
  •  Lower esophagus: leads to esophageal varices, which can rupture and lead to an upper gastrointestinal bleeding. 
  •  In the rectum and anal canal: leads to hemorrhoids, which are also enlarged veins that can bleed 
  •  The veins of the anterior abdominal wall, which anastomose with the paraumbilical veins and become varicose. This looks like small snakes radiating under the skin around the umbilicus and is called caput medusae. 
Signs and symptoms of portal hypertension include palmar erythema, petechiae, ascites, anorectal varices, caput medusae, jaundice, and esophageal varices.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: Portal hypertension can cause blood to back up into the spleen, causing congestive splenomegaly (enlarged spleen). In contrast, pancreatic inflammation can cause blood clot in the splenic vein and can cause gastric varices.  
❌ Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling:
Incorrect: Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling can result from obstruction of left common iliac vein, left external iliac vein, left femoral vein or any other vein in the lower limbs. Portal hypertension can be associated with bilateral ankle swelling.  
✅ Hemorrhoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varicocele:
Incorrect: Varicocele can occur in association with nutcracker syndrome. The pressure in the left renal vein becomes elevated due to the compression in the region where the vein crosses beneath the aorta and superior mesenteric artery. Pressure can be elevated in the left gonadal vein as well, leading to the development of varicocele. The gonadal vein is not a part of the portal system.  
❌ Mallory-Weiss tear:
Incorrect: Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissections) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach that are usually associated with forceful retching. The upper gastrointestinal bleeding seen in association with portal hypertension is due to bleeding esophageal varices.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious on the sidewalk. He is arousable to sternal rub. The patient’s family is contacted, and his next of kin reports that the patient is currently undomiciled. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient has been drinking a pint of vodka daily for the last 12 years, but does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 156/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice, palmar erythema, and pungent breath. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation; there is shifting dullness to percussion. The liver is not palpable. Which of the following is most likely to be present if a biopsy of the patient’s liver is performed?

choices.text: Regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands
Accumulation of glucocerebrosidase within hepatic macrophages
Periodic acid-Schiff positive spherical inclusion bodies in hepatocytes
Hepatocellular swelling and cytoplasmic emptying with diffuse neutrophilic infiltration

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of chronic liver disease (e.g., palmar erythema, jaundice, fetor hepaticus, ascites) and has a history of chronic alcohol use. He most likely has alcoholic cirrhosis. There are several factors that contribute to the pathogenesis of cirrhosis. However, cytokine-mediated activation of stellate cells is well established as the central driver of hepatic fibrosis.  

Cytokines are released when hepatotoxins, such ethanol and its breakdown products, destroy hepatocytes and trigger repair mechanisms. The inflammatory cytokines activate stellate cells, whose normal role is to store vitamin A. However, during states of constant hepatic injury, these quiescent stellate cells transform into proliferative, fibrogenic myoﬁbroblasts, which begin secreting TGF-ꞵ. TGF-ꞵ is a cytokine heavily involved in collagen production. As a result, as stellate cells proliferate and secrete TGF-ꞵ, there is excess collagen production.  

Over time, this constant cycle of destruction and repair leads to fibrosis and abnormal tissue architecture, ultimately impairing normal hepatic exocrine and metabolic function. Macroscopically, the fibrosis leads to a shrunken liver and a nodular liver surface with regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands.


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

✅ Regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prussian-blue staining of hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Positive Prussian-blue staining is indicative of the presence of iron. This finding can be seen in patients with advanced hemochromatosis, wherein there is iron accumulation in various body organs. Although patients with hemochromatosis may present with cirrhosis, they typically have additional characteristic features, such as diabetes mellitus and bronze skin pigmentation.
❌ Accumulation of glucocerebrosidase within hepatic macrophages:
Incorrect: Gaucher disease is due to ꞵ-glucocerebrosidase deficiency and leads to the deposition of glucocerebrosidase within tissue. The condition can cause hepatosplenomegaly, avascular bone necrosis, and anemia. In contrast, this patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Periodic acid-Schiff positive spherical inclusion bodies in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive staining of hepatocytes is suggestive of α1-antitrypsin deficiency, wherein misfolded protein aggregate and damage liver cells. Over time, this aggregation can lead to cirrhosis. Individuals also present with symptoms of severe emphysema (e.g., cough, dyspnea).
❌ Hepatocellular swelling and cytoplasmic emptying with diffuse neutrophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular swelling (“ballooning”) with inflammatory cell infiltration is characteristic of acute viral hepatitis. The condition typically presents with concomitant fever, severe abdominal pain, and jaundice. In acute viral hepatitis, the liver would be enlarged and likely palpable on physical examination. Furthermore, the stigmata of cirrhosis (e.g., palmar erythema, fetor hepaticus) would not be expected in cases of acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of fatigue, jaundice, and pruritus. His symptoms began 1 month ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis, which was diagnosed seven years ago, and hypertension. Family history is positive for cholecystitis in his older sister. In the office, his temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 147/88 mmHg, and pulse is 74/min. Physical examination shows jaundice, scleral icterus, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Total bilirubin  6.5 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  5.9 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  127 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  115 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  142 U/L 
Radiographic imaging and biopsy are scheduled as part of the work-up process. Which of the following findings will be most likely found on this patient’s biopsy?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration of extrahepatic bile ducts only
Fibrosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
Accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes
Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
This patient has primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which is a progressive liver disease characterized by inflammation, fibrosis, and strictures of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree. This finding is classically described as “onion-skin” fibrosis, because on histology, concentric rings of fibrosis around the bile duct can be visualized. PSC is classically diagnosed in middle-aged males with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. The etiology of PSC is unclear, but it is hypothesized to be an autoimmune disorder.  

Most patients complain of abdominal pain, pruritus, fatigue, and jaundice. The pruritis can be disabling, cause excoriations, and reduce quality of life. Patients can also have hepatomegaly.  

Magnetic response cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can confirm the presence of bile-duct strictures and diagnose patients with PSC. There is currently no cure for PSC. However, ursodeoxycholic acid and immunosuppressants can be used to slow disease progression and improve symptoms. Liver transplantation is necessary for patients who develop cirrhosis secondary to PSC.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lymphocytic infiltration of extrahepatic bile ducts only  :
Incorrect: Patients with primary biliary cholangitis may have this biopsy finding. Primary biliary cholangitis is typically found in middle-aged females with autoimmune conditions. In contrast, the patient in this vignette is a male with past history notable for inflammatory bowel disease.
✅ Fibrosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: The accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes would be observed in patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome. The condition can cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, patients with this condition usually have normal liver enzymes and alkaline phosphatase levels. 
❌ Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in patients with biliary atresia. The condition typically affects pediatric patients, manifests in the first few weeks of life, and presents with symptoms including persistent jaundice and darkening of the urine. In contrast, it would be atypical for biliary atresia to develop in a middle-aged male.
❌ Calcification of the gallbladder:
Incorrect: This describes a “porcelain” gallbladder, which occurs when the gallbladder becomes calcified due to chronic cholecystitis. Although the patient has a family history of cholecystitis, he himself has no signs of cholecystitis, such as postprandial pain or Murphy’s sign.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. He recently returned from a trip to the Carribbean and began feeling ill on the return flight. He ate local foods there, including oysters and crabs. He states he is otherwise healthy but does drink 6-7 alcoholic beverages daily. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient has jaundice of the buccal mucosa. Palpation of the right upper quadrant elicits significant pain. Laboratory results are as follows:


The patient is referred for liver biopsy, with histologic findings demonstrated below:


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following findings is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Ballooning degeneration of zone I hepatocytes
Bridging necrosis of zone III hepatocytes
Granulomatous degeneration of zone II hepatocytes
Thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein
Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and jaundice after eating oysters. The laboratory findings demonstrate an increase in ALT relative to AST, and the liver biopsy demonstrates councilman bodies. Together, these findings are consistent with viral hepatitis, most likely due to hepatitis A. Zone I is the region of the liver lobule primarily affected by viral hepatitis.  

Viral hepatitis refers to infection of hepatocytes caused by the hepatitis viruses A, B, C, D, and E. Regardless of the type of virus, the pathologic degeneration and zone of the liver lobule affected remains the same. Infection of hepatocytes in zone I results in hepatocyte injury and “ballooning degeneration” followed by hepatocyte death and “bridging necrosis.” Over time, this process results in the presence of councilman bodies or apoptotic globules of cells that represent a dying hepatocyte and panlobular mononuclear infiltration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ballooning degeneration of zone I hepatocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bridging necrosis of zone III hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Ethanol, halothane, and rifampin are associated with damage to zone III hepatocytes. This site has a high concentration of CYP-450 enzymes and is highly susceptible to toxic metabolites. This patient has an increase in ALT relative to AST, making alcoholic hepatitis less likely.
❌ Granulomatous degeneration of zone II hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis or tuberculosis can result in granulomatous degeneration of the differing regions of the liver lobule. Yellow fever is associated with damage to hepatocytes in zone II; however, it is not associated with granulomatous degeneration.
❌ Thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome refers to thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein. While this patient has recently returned from a long distance flight, he does not have a clinical history or other stigmata, such as active hepatocellular carcinoma, that would place him at risk for developing this condition.
❌ Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cirrhosis results in fibrosis between nodules of hepatocytes. While this patient does consume significant amounts of alcohol, the liver biopsy does not demonstrate fibrotic liver architecture.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of abdominal pain and itching. The symptoms began several months ago but have progressively worsened. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease, which is well managed with a gluten-free diet. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. There is no scleral icterus or jaundice. Laboratory results are as follows:



A liver biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathological changes would most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Hepatocytes with swollen endoplasmic reticulum due to increased viral proteins
Destruction of of intrahepatic biliary ducts and periductal fibrosis
Central vein with surrounding congestion and necrosis

questions.solution:
Autoimmune hepatitis (AH) is a form of chronic hepatitis that predominantly affects females (78%), and more specifically young and middle-aged females. The exact origin of the condition is unclear; however, it is commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., celiac disease, ulcerative colitis, systemic lupus erythematosus). Triggers for the immune reaction may include viral infections, toxin exposure, and drugs.  

The clinical presentation of AH can vary from an acute clinical illness to fulminant liver failure resulting in hepatic encephalopathy. Symptoms may include weight loss, fatigue, fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain.  

A characteristic finding in most patients with AH is the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies. As antibodies attack the liver, inflammation results in elevated liver enzymes and hepatomegaly. Biopsy findings in patients with AH include necrosis, inflammation, and plasma cell infiltration. Since AH is autoimmune in origin, therapy consists of immunosuppression, such as with high-dose steroids.



Option Analysis

✅ Portal plasma cell infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocytes with swollen endoplasmic reticulum due to increased viral proteins:
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis B can result in “ground glass” hepatocytes, which occur due to accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen within the endoplasmic reticulum. However, this patient has positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies, which makes another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Destruction of of intrahepatic biliary ducts and periductal fibrosis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of interlobular bile ducts. Although initial stages may present similarly to autoimmune hepatitis, the patient’s normal alkaline phosphatase makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Widespread lipid accumulation in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is typically seen in patients with obesity and/or have type II diabetes. Insulin resistance and obesity results in increased free fatty acid mobilization from adipose tissue and subsequent liver uptake. This patient has a normal BMI and blood glucose level, hence making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Central vein with surrounding congestion and necrosis:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in congestive hepatopathy, wherein outflow of blood from the hepatic veins is hindered due to increased right atrial and vena caval pressures. This is commonly seen in patients with right-sided heart failure, which typically presents with jugular venous distension and lower extremity edema; these symptoms are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with worsening fatigue and arthralgias. She reports her symptoms started 2-3 weeks ago and states that her eyes have looked “discolored.” She has a history of chronic alcohol use but does not use illicit drugs. She had unprotected sexual intercourse several months ago. She has never received blood products. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for scleral icterus and hepatomegaly. Blood titers are positive for a DNA hepadnavirus, and she subsequently undergoes liver biopsy. Which of the following best describes the most likely histologic features of this patient’s biopsy specimen?

choices.text: Lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis
Spotty necrosis and portal expansion with inflammatory infiltrates
Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, malaise, and recent unprotected sexual intercourse. The workup is notable for titers positive for a DNA hepadnavirus, consistent with hepatitis B infection. Of the histologic descriptions listed, a ground glass appearance of hepatocytes is most consistent with hepatitis B infection.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. Following inoculation, hepatitis B infects hepatocytes via a bile salt transporter and enters the cell. During the proliferative phase, viral HBsAg and HBcAg are produced in abundance within the hepatocyte cytoplasm and are ultimately expressed on the hepatocyte cell surface. The cytoplasm's granular homogeneous eosinophilic staining is caused by the presence of HBsAg. Abundant hepatitis B antigen in the endoplasmic reticulum results in the “ground-glass” appearance of hepatocytes. Ultimately, viral HBsAg and HBcAg expressed on the hepatocyte cell surface trigger an immune response by cytotoxic T-cells, resulting in hepatocellular damage.

Option Analysis

✅ Granular eosinophilic "ground-glass" appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis:
Incorrect: Biopsy specimens in patients with hepatitis C will typically demonstrate lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis. Hepatitis C is primarily transmitted parenterally, and this patient does not have risk factors for bloodborne transmission.
❌ Hepatocyte swelling and monocyte infiltration:
Incorrect: Biopsy specimens in patients with hepatitis A will typically demonstrate hepatocyte swelling and monocyte infiltration—as will most presentations of acute hepatitis, which tends to present with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain.
❌ Spotty necrosis and portal expansion with inflammatory infiltrates:
Incorrect: Hepatitis E results in areas of patchy necrosis on biopsy. It is rare in the United States and poses a high risk to pregnant patients and those with underlying liver disease.
❌ Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cirrhosis is unlikely in this patient without other evidence of end-stage liver disease including ascites, bleeding dyscrasias, or spider angiomata.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic due to abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and weight loss for the past three months. He states the pain is mainly in the right upper quadrant and describes the pain as vague, 3/10, and constant. He immigrated from Bolivia 2 years ago. Immunizations are up to date. Medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an icteric patient. On abdominal examination, pain is produced when pressure is applied to the right subcostal area. An abdominal ultrasound examination shows calcification within the gallbladder. When the patient is asked to lie on his side, the calcifications are observed at the same location. Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with constitutional signs (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), vague progressive abdominal pain, and jaundice; this presentation, in conjunction with the abdominal ultrasound findings, suggests a malignancy of the gallbladder. The ultrasound exam depicts a calcified mass that does not move with position change, indicating that the mass is fixed rather than moveable like gallstones.

Gallbladder cancer (GBC) is a rare but highly fatal malignancy. The most common types are adenocarcinomas and less commonly squamous cell carcinoma, small cell neuroendocrine tumors, lymphoma, and sarcoma. The majority of cases are found incidentally in patients undergoing exploration for cholelithiasis. The poor prognosis is likely to be due to the typically advanced stage at the time of diagnosis, which is thought to be the result of both the anatomic position of the gallbladder and the nonspecific symptoms of the condition. Patients with early invasive disease are usually asymptomatic or may present with nonspecific symptoms that mimic or are due to cholelithiasis or cholecystitis. Among symptomatic patients, common presenting symptoms are pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, malaise, and weight loss. Patients with GBC may also present with obstructive jaundice, either from invasion of the biliary tree or from metastases to the area of the hepatoduodenal ligament.  

Multiple risk factors have been identified to be associated with GBC: 
  •  Gallstone disease ‐ a history of gallstones appears to be one of the strongest risk factors for the development of GBC 
  •  Porcelain gallbladder ‐ an uncommon manifestation of chronic cholecystitis that is characterized by intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall 
  •  Gallbladder polyps ‐ outgrowths of the gallbladder mucosal wall that are usually found incidentally on ultrasonography and can be classified as benign or malignant lesions 
  •  Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) ‐ a chronic inflammatory state associated with ulcerative colitis 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatitis B infection:
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis B infection is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder. Additionally, this patient has updated immunizations.   
❌ Primary biliary cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by progressive destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts of the liver, scarring, and fibrosis. It is commonly seen in middle-aged women. It is associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis), but it is not associated with adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder.   
✅ Gallstone disease  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Ionizing radiation:
Incorrect: Ionizing radiation is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma and leukemias. It is not associated with adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder.   
❌ Clonorchis sinensis infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis, a trematode (fluke), increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, a cancer of the bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinoma, like other malignancies, can present with fatigue, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, an abdominal ultrasound would instead show biliary ductal dilatation, rather than a calcified mass within the gallbladder.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent crampy abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last five days. She had an episode of vomiting with hematemesis six hours ago. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, gallstones, and hypertension. Current medications are metformin and lisinopril. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows distention and tenderness, and hyperactive high-pitched bowel sounds are heard on auscultation. An abdominal radiograph shows pneumobilia and dilated loops of small bowel. Laboratory results are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value Result 
Leukocyte count  23,250/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  46% 
 Platelets  400,000/µL 
 Lipase  140 U/L 
 AST, SGOT  47 U/L 
 ALT, SGPT  45 U/L 
 Total bilirubin  0.8 mg/dL 
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of gallstones and is presenting with intermittent abdominal pain with persistent nausea and vomiting and an episode of hematemesis. The physical examination features suggest a bowel obstruction (e.g. abdominal distension, hyperactive high-pitched bowel sounds). Finally, the abdominal radiograph shows dilated loops of small bowel associated with pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree), which indicates a small bowel obstruction due to a gallstone lodged in the ileocecal valve, known as gallstone ileus. The term “ileus” is a misnomer because the obstruction is a true mechanical phenomenon. This condition is often seen in elderly individuals who have significant comorbidities.  

The pathogenesis begins with cholelithiasis complicated by cholecystitis. The impacted gallstone causes inflammation and pressure buildup within the gallbladder, which leads to the inflamed gallbladder’s adhesion to surrounding structures. This adhesion leads to the formation of a fistula between the gallbladder and intestine (biliary-enteric or cholecystoenteric fistula). Once fistulization has occurred, a large enough stone can enter the intestine and lodge at the ileocecal valve, leading to a small bowel obstruction. Transient gallstone impaction produces abdominal pain and vomiting, which subside when the gallstone is dislodged.    


Gallstone ileus should be suspected in patients with the above presentation in addition to radiologic evaluation. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) is most often used, but a plain radiograph can be used when CT is unavailable. The Rigler triad describes the presentation of gallstone ileus on plain radiograph and includes pneumobilia, small bowel obstruction, and an obstructing gallstone. Treatment involves symptomatic management, nasogastric suctioning, and emergency surgery. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Emphysematous cholecystitis:
Incorrect: Emphysematous cholecystitis is an acute infection of the gallbladder wall by gas-forming bacteria, which is considered a medical emergency. Similar to acute cholecystitis, patients with emphysematous cholecystitis present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. It can also cause air in the biliary tree; however, dilated loops of small bowel would not be consistent with this diagnosis.   
❌ Superior mesenteric artery syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome is an unusual cause of proximal intestinal obstruction. This condition involves the compression of the third portion of the duodenum due to narrowing of the space between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. It is most often caused by significant weight loss leading to loss of the mesenteric fat. However, this patient has pneumobilia on the abdominal radiograph, which would not be present in SMA syndrome.  
❌ Colonic pseudo-obstruction:
Incorrect: Colonic pseudo-obstruction, also known as Ogilvie syndrome, is characterized by acute dilation of the colon in the absence of mechanical obstruction. It is often seen in acutely sick patients or with the use of certain medications (e.g., opioids). Patients present with signs of large bowel obstruction. This patient has a small bowel obstruction with air present in the biliary tree, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Diverticulitis :
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is often seen in elderly patients, but it usually presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and hematochezia. Air seen under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray would be concerning for a perforation; however, air in the biliary tree would not be expected.  
❌ Acute hepatitis :
Incorrect: Acute hepatitis infection presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, malaise, and anorexia. Within a few days, dark urine and pale stools appear, followed by jaundice and pruritus. This patient’s radiograph instead demonstrates a small bowel obstruction with air present in the biliary tree, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
✅ Mechanical bowel obstruction:
Correct: See main explanation

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of weight loss, fatigue, and abdominal pain. He reports a gradual onset of symptoms several weeks ago that have not abated. He has a burning pain in his hands and feet that has followed a similar time course. He has a past medical history of hypertension, does not smoke or use alcohol, and has a history of intravenous heroin use. The last time he used IV heroin was 6 months ago. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 167/92 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a mottled reticulated vascular pattern on the arms and legs. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL. An arteriogram is performed and demonstrates the following finding:


 Reproduced from:

Which of the following pathologic features is most likely associated with this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with multiple constitutional symptoms and a physical examination describing livedo reticularis. The work-up is notable for kidney dysfunction as well as beading and numerous microaneurysms affecting the segmental, interlobar, and arcuate vessels on an arterial nephrogram. This presentation is consistent with polyarteritis nodosa, a medium-vessel vasculitis due to immune complex deposition that carries a high association with concurrent hepatitis B infection.  

Hepatitis B presents with multiple extrahepatic manifestations that are thought to be immune-mediated. Examples include skin rashes, arthritis, and arthralgias. Additional manifestations include aplastic anemia, membranous glomerulonephritis, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and polyarteritis nodosa. Nearly 30% of individuals with polyarteritis nodosa have concurrent hepatitis B infection.  


Option Analysis

✅ Deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive for HLA-B51:
Incorrect: HLA-B51 is associated with Behçet's disease which manifests with recurrent aphthous ulcers, genital ulcerations, uveitis, and erythema nodosum. The disease can be precipitated by HSV or parvovirus and results in small-vessel vasculitis.
❌ Cryoglobulin immune complex deposition:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C infection is associated with essential, mixed cryoglobulinemia. In contrast, this patient’s presentation with livedo reticularis and likely polyarteritis nodosa is suggestive of hepatitis B, which is not associated with cryoglobulin immune complex deposition.
❌ Anti-GpIIb/IIIa antibodies :
Incorrect: HIV and hepatitis C, as well as autoimmune disorders and malignancy, may predispose patients to the development of immune thrombocytopenia. This patient, whose presentation is consistent with polyarteritis nodosa, likely has a different underlying infection.   
❌ Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase:
Incorrect: A deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, an enzyme involved in heme synthesis, is consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda, which is associated with hepatitis C infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation with livedo reticularis and likely polyarteritis nodosa is suggestive of hepatitis B.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old female comes to the physician for evaluation of shortness of breath over the past few months. She has had no fever or weight loss over this time period. Past medical history is noncontributory and she does not take any medications. The patient drinks 2 or 3 glasses of wine on the weekends and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the expiratory phase is prolonged and scattered wheezes are heard bilaterally. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin. No palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites are noted. Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes. Pulmonary function testing is performed and is shown below:

Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The physician suspects a genetic condition. Which of the following is most likely to reveal the cause of this patient’s underlying disease process?

choices.text: Serum levels of a protease inhibitor

questions.solution:
This patient has pulmonary and hepatic symptoms despite not smoking and consuming only minimal quantities of alcohol. Her presentation is concerning for the autosomal dominant condition known as α1-antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency.  

A1AT is a protease inhibitor produced primarily by hepatocytes. Functional A1AT inhibits proteolytic enzymes such as neutrophil elastase, which is found within macrophages and the primary granules of neutrophils. Normally, elastase helps combat infections by degrading bacterial virulence factors. However, patients with A1AT deficiency produce misfolded copies of the protein that are unable to inhibit elastase. The uninhibited elastase activity leads to destruction of fibers in the alveolar walls and gives rise to panacinar emphysema (as indicated by this patient’s obstructive lung disease pattern on pulmonary function testing). Furthermore, the misfolded A1AT proteins accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, leading to cell engorgement, release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately causing apoptosis and inflammation. This chronic inflammation of the liver results in hepatitis and eventual cirrhosis.  

Diagnosis of A1AT primarily depends upon measuring serum alpha-1 antitrypsin levels, where patients with the condition would have significantly lower levels present in their serum. Pulmonary function testing should also be performed, and would demonstrate an obstructive lung disease pattern. Treatment involves intravenous replacement with pooled alpha-1 antitrypsin.  



Option Analysis

✅ Serum levels of a protease inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum ferritin levels:
Incorrect: Serum ferritin would be helpful in the diagnosis of hemochromatosis, which may also present with signs of liver damage (e.g., enlarged liver, elevated liver enzymes). However, patients would also have other signs of iron-overload, such as diabetes mellitus, arthropathy, and eventually, skin pigmentation. This patient’s additional symptoms of obstructive lung disease is characteristic of another underlying condition.
❌ Sweat chloride test:
Incorrect: Sweat chloride tests can be used in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF), which is characterized by recurrent pneumonia, sinusitis, and malabsorptive symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, poor weight gain). However, CF is almost always diagnosed before adulthood, and is unlikely to be the diagnosis in this older patient.
❌ 24-hour urinary copper excretion:
Incorrect: Wilson disease is caused by excessive copper accumulation in the liver eventually leading to the development of cirrhosis, as well as additional neurological manifestations. This patient’s constellation of liver injury and obstructive lung disease, however, is suggestive of a different underlying condition.
❌ Viral hepatitis panel:
Incorrect: Patients with chronic hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C), may eventually present with signs of liver damage and cirrhosis. However, viral etiologies of hepatitis are unlikely to also result in obstructive lung disease, as seen in this patient’s pulmonary function testing.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department after multiple episodes of painless hematemesis. He was at home eating dinner when he felt nauseous and vomited bright red blood. The patient has multiple prior admissions for alcohol intoxication. He has been drinking a pint of vodka daily for the last 15 years. He does not smoke cigarettes. The patient tried heroin several years ago, but has not used it since. Past medical history is otherwise not significant for any abnormal bleeding episodes. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/74 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and engorged paraumbilical veins. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Despite appropriate management, the patient is told there is a high likelihood of his symptoms recurring. Which of the following best explains why this patient is likely to experience a similar episode in the future?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with esophageal variceal bleeding due to underlying liver cirrhosis caused by excessive alcohol consumption. Patients with liver cirrhosis also have reduced levels of thrombin (as well as many other clotting factors), which would predispose them to future episodes of bleeding.  

In patients with liver cirrhosis, hepatic fibrosis and hepatocyte apoptosis can reduce the liver’s synthetic capabilities. The hepatocyte is normally involved in various functions, including:  

  • Uptake and conjugation of bilirubin by uridine diphosphate (UDP)-glucuronosyltransferase in the endoplasmic reticulum. As hepatocytes lose their ability to function in cirrhosis, there is increased unconjugated bilirubin due to loss of this enzyme, which results in jaundice.   
  • Albumin makes up the majority of plasma proteins and is exclusively produced by the liver. As the synthetic capacity of the liver decreases, hypoalbuminemia occurs, which can lead to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and development of interstitial edema.   
  • The hepatocyte is the site of production of nearly all coagulation factors including fibrinogen (factor I), thrombin (factor II), and upstream factors V, VII, IX, X, and XI, with the prominent exception being factor VIII. Loss of these factors results in increased risk for bleeding -- for example, from esophageal varices.  


Option Analysis

✅ Impaired production of thrombin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombocytosis:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis, can be present in patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Due to decreased venous drainage secondary to portal hypertension, the spleen can enlarge in size and cause platelet sequestration. The resulting thrombocytopenia can lead to increased episodes of bleeding.
❌ Reduced synthesis of factor VIII:
Incorrect: Factor VIII levels are generally unaffected in patients with cirrhosis since it is one of the few coagulation factors that is not produced by the liver. Instead, factor VIII is produced in endothelial cells.
❌ Inherited coagulopathy:
Incorrect: Inherited coagulopathies (e.g., hemophilia, von Willebrand disease) can result in episodes of bleeding. This patient’s history is not significant for any abnormal bleeding episodes prior to his current symptoms. Furthermore, his concurrent cirrhosis makes another etiology more likely.
❌ Systemic activation of coagulation products:
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is characterized by systemic activation of the clotting cascade with subsequent microthrombi formation and exhaustion of clotting factors. DIC commonly occurs secondary to other disorders, such as sepsis or malignancy. Although this patient is at increased risk of infection due to his underlying liver disease, another etiology is more likely to cause recurrent esophageal variceal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the primary care physician after sustaining a needle stick injury at work. He works as a nurse in the emergency department and reports he sustained an accidental needlestick injury in the emergency department several weeks ago while placing an IV line. He did not initially seek treatment as he was asymptomatic, but he became concerned after he developed fatigue, malaise, and a low-grade fever several days ago. His laboratory findings are demonstrated below:

If left untreated which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this disease process?
questions.solution:
This healthcare worker presents after sustaining a needlestick injury at work, and his laboratory findings are consistent with chronic hepatitis C infection and previous hepatitis B vaccination. Of the clinical courses listed, most patients with hepatitis C go on to develop a chronic infection and carrier state.  

Hepatitis C is an enveloped single-stranded RNA flavivirus that is primarily transmitted parenterally—e.g. through needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions. Most patients who become infected undergo a long incubation period (2 weeks to 6 months) before symptoms, if any, develop. After acute symptoms, which are usually non-specific viral symptoms, the majority of patients (50-85%) go on to be chronic carriers of hepatitis C, while a minority spontaneously clear the infection.  

Around 5-30% of patients who are chronic carriers develop cirrhosis and end-stage liver disease, which may ultimately be the only signs of infection, even after 20-30 years of viral incubation. Of the patients who develop cirrhosis, a small percentage—approximately 5%—will go on to develop hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic infection and carrier state:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete resolution:
Incorrect: Approximately 20-30% of patients will completely clear hepatitis C following acute infection. In contrast, approximately 95% of primary hepatitis B infections in immunocompetent adults are self-limited, with elimination of the virus from blood and general immunity to reinfection.
❌ Cirrhosis:
Incorrect: Of patients who develop chronic hepatitis C, approximately 10-20% will go on to develop cirrhosis after 20-30 years of active infection.
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: There is an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with hepatitis C infection; however, it is not the most common clinical course.
❌ Superinfection:
Incorrect: Superinfection occurs when a patient who is a chronic carrier of hepatitis B becomes infected with hepatitis D. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows immunity against hepatitis B (positive anti-HBs), with a current hepatitis C infection.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female comes to her primary care provider due to fatigue and intense pruritus for the last 2 months. She works as a schoolteacher and has felt excessive daytime somnolence that is interfering with her job. Past medical history is significant for chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis, for which she has been taking daily levothyroxine. She drinks 1-2 glasses of wine on the weekends and denies smoking tobacco or using illicit substances. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals multiple excoriations on her trunk and extremities. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is not tender to palpation. Laboratory results are as follows:



Which of the following complications is associated with this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pruritus, fatigue, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated alkaline phosphatase, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and anti-mitochondrial antibodies. These findings are suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which predisposes patients to osteoporosis and pathologic fractures.  

PBC is an autoimmune disease that results in inflammatory destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. Unlike primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), the extrahepatic biliary tree is unaffected. PBC primarily affects middle-aged women, with a peak incidence between 40-50 years of age.  

Most patients are diagnosed while asymptomatic because of abnormalities in routine liver biochemical tests, such as elevated serum alkaline phosphatase or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Patients are also positive for anti-mitochondrial antibodies.  

Common clinical symptoms arise from cholestasis, such as fatigue and pruritus. Early treatment with oral ursodeoxycholic acid has been shown to significantly slow disease progression, likely due to its ability to enter the bile acid pool and alter the biochemical composition of bile. However, even with treatment, patients are at increased risk of osteomalacia and osteoporosis. The exact mechanism behind this association is unclear, but is thought to be a result of several factors, including 1) malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins secondary to decreased bile acid secretion and 2) reduced new bone formation.



Option Analysis

✅ Femoral neck fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pretibial and periorbital edema:
Incorrect: Generalized myxedema can be seen in patients with hypothyroidism due to increased deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the dermis and mucous membranes. This patient has a normal TSH level, suggesting that her hypothyroidism is well managed.
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease:
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, can be seen in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC can present similarly to primary biliary cholangitis; however, patients with PSC will typically be positive for p-ANCA antibodies, not anti-mitochondrial antibodies.
❌ Cholangiocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Cholangiocarcinoma is a complication of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which may present similarly to PBC. The risk for cholangiocarcinoma may be slightly increased in patients with PBC, but the association is still unclear.
❌ Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels:
Incorrect: Polyarteritis nodosa, a systemic vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels, can be seen in patients with hepatitis B infection. This patient’s laboratory results are positive for anti-HBsAg antibodies, which indicates the patient is immune to hepatitis B and does not have a chronic infection.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the clinic due to worsening fatigue and abdominal distension. The patient has lost 11 pounds in the last 2 months with minimal change in appetite. Past medical history is notable for chronic liver disease due to hepatitis B infection that was diagnosed 15 years ago. His most recent colonoscopy 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 154/89 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting and scleral icterus. Palmar erythema and multiple spider angiomas are present. The abdomen is distended with shifting dullness to percussion. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Ultrasound shows a single homogenous liver mass with irregular borders. Which of the following best describes the tumor marker that is likely elevated in this patient?

choices.text: Glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac
Hormone produced by the placenta after embryonal implantation
Cell-surface glycoprotein found on Müllerian-type epithelium
Protein normally present in cells derived from the neural crest

questions.solution:
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a malignant, usually solitary, tumor of the liver that primarily occurs in patients with preexisting liver cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis. The most important underlying factors in HCC are viral infections (e.g., hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus) and toxin-mediated injuries (e.g., aflatoxin, alcohol). These factors cause the liver to be in a constant cycle of damage and repair, which raise the chances of genetic mutations, potentially leading to carcinogenesis and development of HCC. Therefore, in regions where HBV and HCV (and therefore, cirrhosis) are common, there is a high incidence of HCC.  

Clinical manifestations of HCC are typically due to underlying cirrhosis (e.g., ascites, pitting edema), but patients may also present with systemic signs such as weight loss, malaise, and fatigue. As the tumor grows, abdominal distension and anorexia (due to compression of the stomach) may occur. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker associated with HCC. AFP is a glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac, and is therefore also elevated in yolk sac tumors. Additional diagnostic studies involve liver imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT, MRI) and would typically show a hypodense lesion with irregular borders.  




Image reproduced from

Option Analysis

✅ Glycoprotein normally produced by the fetal yolk sac:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hormone produced by the placenta after embryonal implantation:
Incorrect: ꞵ-hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta after implantation. It can be used as a tumor-marker to detect recurrence and response to treatment for seminomas, choriocarcinomas, germ cell tumors, and teratomas; however, it is not typically elevated in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Glycoprotein involved in cell adhesion:
Incorrect: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a group of proteins involved in cell adhesion and is normally produced during embryonic development by cells of the gastrointestinal tract; therefore, it is commonly elevated in patients with colorectal cancer. However, it would not be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Cell-surface glycoprotein found on Müllerian-type epithelium:
Incorrect: Carcinoembryonic antigen-125 (CA-125) is a cell-surface glycoprotein found on cells derived from the Müllerian ducts. The Müllerian ducts form the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper ⅓ of the vagina. CA-125 is used as a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and other tumors arising from the Müllerian ducts. However, it is unlikely to be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Protein normally present in cells derived from the neural crest:
Incorrect: S-100 is a cytoplasmic protein that can be used as a tumor marker on immunohistochemical staining, especially in cells derived from the neural crest. It is usually associated with malignant melanoma, neurofibromas, and peripheral sheath tumors. It would not be elevated in this patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to right-sided abdominal pain for the past two hours. She states the pain started after she had lunch, which consisted of a burger and fries. She describes the pain as dull and 5/10 in intensity. Medical history is significant for Crohn disease diagnosed 3 years ago. Medications include methotrexate and ustekinumab. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows sensitivity to touch in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple stones within the gallbladder. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with Crohn disease most likely developed gallstones due to damage to the terminal ileum, leading to the malabsorption of bile acid.     Bile acid is produced by the liver cells, secreted into the bile, and then released into the intestines to aid in digestion. It is then used for fat emulsification (breaking fat droplets into smaller pieces to maximize surface area for digestion), which facilitates fat and cholesterol absorption in the form of micelles. The outline of bile acid synthesis and reabsorption is summarized in the following steps:  

  •  The liver cells synthesize primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) by cytochrome P450-mediated oxidation of cholesterol in a multi-step process, involving the rate-limiting enzyme 7α-hydroxylase; this process is one of the few methods the body has to excrete cholesterol from the body.  
  •  The liver cells then conjugate primary bile acids with the amino acids glycine or taurine to form conjugated bile acids, making them relatively insoluble in water and unable to be reabsorbed in the intestines. 
  •  Once secreted into the intestine, the gut microbiota remove the glycine and taurine groups, forming secondary bile acids. Secondary bile acids are deconjugated and available for reabsorption in the terminal ileum.     

Approximately 600 mg of bile salts are synthesized every day to replace bile acids lost in the feces. However, most of the bile is reabsorbed by active transport in the terminal ileum and recycled, a process known as enterohepatic circulation. Crohn disease commonly damages the terminal ileum, the location of bile acid reabsorption. The reduced bile acid pool leads to an imbalance between cholesterol and bile acids within the gallbladder, leading to supersaturation of cholesterol and subsequent gallstone formation.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant, whereas ustekinumab is a human monoclonal antibody; both of these agents are used to treat Crohn disease. Neither, however, is associated with gallstone formation.   
❌ Reduced cholecystokinin secretion:
Incorrect: Reduced cholecystokinin secretion can lead to hypomobility of the gallbladder, which increases the risk of gallstone formation. It can be seen in patients with somatostatinomas (due to inhibition of cholecystokinin release), with spinal cord injuries, or receiving total parenteral nutrition.    
❌ Hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Chronic hemolysis increases the risk for formation of black pigment stones, due to increased levels of bilirubin. Crohn disease can present with anemia due to malabsorption of B12 or due to chronic inflammatory state (anemia of chronic disease); however, these are not causes of hemolytic anemia.    
✅ Bile acid wasting:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Infection of the biliary tree:
Incorrect: Ascending cholangitis is an inflammation of the bile system due to bacterial invasion secondary to partial bile duct obstruction. Common presenting symptoms are fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice (Charcot triad), with occasional hypotension and altered mental status (Reynolds pentad). This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department seeking evaluation for abdominal pain which began 12 hours ago. The pain is localized in the right upper quadrant and is rated as 7 out of 10 in severity. In addition, she has had two episodes of non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 152/88 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Physical examination shows jaundice, and pain is elicited on palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory testing reveals a total serum bilirubin of 6.7 mg/dL. Ultrasound reveals obstruction in a portion of the common bile duct. No obstruction or dilation of the pancreatic duct or hepatopancreatic duct is observed. Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has choledocolithiasis, which occurs when a gallstone lodges in the common bile duct. Patients can present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Since bile outflow is obstructed, patients will develop conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  

In addition to gallstones, tumors (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic adenocarcinoma), strictures, and parasitic infections can also cause biliary tract obstruction. Patients with chronic biliary tract obstruction can have pale stools (since bilirubin breakdown products give stool its brown color) and dark urine (since the conjugated bilirubin is instead excreted via urine). In addition, patients can have malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins and hypercholesterolemia. The latter is most likely due to leakage of cholesterol and lecithin from ruptured biliary ductules into the bloodstream and increased hepatic cholesterol synthesis.  

On laboratory testing, individuals with biliary tract obstruction can have elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamate transpeptidase levels. If the obstruction causes liver injury, then aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) levels can also be elevated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated lipase:
Incorrect: If the portion of the common bile duct distal to the pancreatic duct is obstructed, then pancreatic enzyme outflow can be impaired. This impairment can cause pancreatitis and elevated lipase levels. However, this patient has an obstruction in a portion of the common bile duct proximal to the pancreatic duct. In this scenario, lipase levels would likely be normal.  
✅ Elevated alkaline phosphatase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal aspartate transaminase levels:
Incorrect: This patient has acute onset right upper quadrant pain, which is concerning for a gallstone-related etiology. If the common bile duct is affected, then the condition is termed choledocolithiasis. Obstruction of the common bile duct will impair bile excretion. This causes bile to backflow into the liver, causing damage and increasing liver enzyme levels.   
❌ Elevated unconjugated bilirubin:
Incorrect: Conditions such as Gilbert syndrome or hemolytic anemias can cause elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. However, an etiology that affects the common bile duct will likely impair bile outflow, resulting in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Elevated carbohydrate antigen 19-9:
Incorrect: Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer. A pancreatic mass can potentially obstruct the common bile duct. However, the patient in this vignette has a history of acute onset right upper quadrant pain in the absence of weight loss, night sweats, or other systemic symptoms. This is more consistent with the presentation of a gallstone-related etiology.

questions.text: A 72-year-old hospitalized man is evaluated for abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. He was admitted two weeks ago for coronary artery bypass surgery, which was complicated by mediastinitis. He underwent surgical debridement and is now receiving IV antibiotics and total parenteral nutrition. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. He has had no history of gallstones or abdominal pain. For the past 24 hours, the patient has been experiencing fever, abdominal pain, right shoulder pain, nausea, and vomiting. Today, the nurse noticed he began to develop mild jaundice of the skin. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Leukocyte count is 17,000 mm3. During imaging, respiratory arrest is observed when the ultrasound probe is applied over the right subcostal area; ultrasound results are equivocal due to body habitus. Laparoscopic surgery is planned. Which of the following set of findings is most likely to be seen in this patient during surgery?

choices.text: Fibrosed and thickened gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones

questions.solution:
This severely ill patient, now presenting with fever, jaundice, leukocytosis, and abdominal pain with positive sonographic Murphy sign, is most likely suffering from acalculous cholecystitis.  

Acalculous cholecystitis (a-calculous = no stone) refers to an acute necroinflammatory disease of the gallbladder in the absence of gallstones due to various causes. The condition is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. It is thought to occur due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia, leading to a local inflammatory response of the gallbladder wall. Risk factors include causes of gallbladder stasis:  

  •  Infections (e.g. CMV) 
  •  Immunosuppression (e.g. AIDS) 
  •  Trauma  
  •  Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) 
  •  Sepsis 
  •  Burns 
It is commonly seen in critically ill patients, as seen here. The clinical presentation varies and depends on the severity of illness and underlying condition. Patients may present with unexplained fever or classic right upper abdominal pain associated with jaundice. Laboratory tests are non-specific, but leukocytosis is present in the majority of the cases. Abnormal liver tests with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, mild increase in serum alkaline phosphatase and serum aminotransferases can also be seen. Complications of acalculous cholecystitis include emphysematous cholecystitis, gangrene, and perforation. Treatment of acalculous cholecystitis consists of supportive care with intravenous fluids, pain control, and antibiotics, followed by definitive therapy with either gallbladder drainage (cholecystostomy) or cholecystectomy.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gallbladder inflammation; pigment gallstones:
Incorrect: Pigment stones can be either black, due hemolysis, or brown, due to a liver fluke. Both can cause cholecystitis; however, this patient has no history of hemolysis or travel to endemic areas with liver fluke (Asia). In addition, this patient is severely ill and receiving total parenteral nutrition, favoring another diagnosis.
❌ Gallbladder inflammation; cholesterol gallstones:
Incorrect: Cholesterol gallstones are the most common cause of cholecystitis. Risk factors for cholesterol gallstones include obesity, Crohn disease, advanced age, estrogen therapy, multiparity, and rapid weight loss. Although the patient has some of the risk factors for cholesterol gallstones, he has no prior history. Also, this patient is severely ill and receiving total parenteral nutrition, favoring another diagnosis.
✅ Gallbladder inflammation; no gallstones:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Porcelain gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones:
Incorrect: Porcelain gallbladder is caused by calcification of the gallbladder due to chronic cholecystitis and is usually found incidentally on imaging. Patients are often asymptomatic. It has been associated with increased risk for gallbladder cancer (mostly adenocarcinoma).
❌ Fibrosed and thickened gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones :
Incorrect: Fibrosis and thickening gallbladder can be seen in chronic cholecystitis. It is thought to be the result of mechanical irritation or recurrent attacks of acute cholecystitis, leading to fibrosis and thickening of the gallbladder wall. However, its presence does not always correlate with symptoms.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old male presents for evaluation of intense pruritus and fatigue over the last 5 weeks. He is a construction worker and has found it difficult to complete tasks due to constant tiredness. He has not been to a physician in over 10 years because of financial concerns. The patient has not had any recent abdominal pain or diarrhea, but has had multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea that self-resolved several years ago. He drinks 2-3 beers on the weekends but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and multiple excoriations over the trunk and arms. There is no tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals the following:



Which of the following additional findings is likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Colonoscopy showing friable mucosa with superficial ulcerations
Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound showing gallbladder wall thickening and edema
Intestinal biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas and lymphoid aggregates
Positive anti-hepatitis A virus IgM antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient has pruritus, fatigue, scleral icterus, and positive p-ANCA antibodies as well as a history of intermittent bloody bowel movements. These findings are suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and undiagnosed ulcerative colitis, which manifests with an inflamed, reddened mucosa with superficial ulcerations on colonoscopy.  

PSC is characterized by chronic autoimmune-mediated inflammation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Although the precise etiology is unclear, there is a strong association with autoimmune diseases, and in particular ulcerative colitis (UC). 90% of patients with PSC have an underlying diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); nearly 90% of these IBD patients have UC while the remaining 10% have Crohn disease. The autoimmune nature of PSC is further reinforced by the presence of T-cells in the periductal stroma on biopsy.  

Clinical symptoms may include jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. If untreated, patients may go on to develop cirrhosis. Laboratory testing will typically be positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA). Since PSC affects both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, irregular biliary strictures and dilations result in a characteristic “beading” pattern on MRCP.
