Unlike primary biliary cholangitis, there is no medication that can consistently prevent disease progression; currently, ursodeoxycholic acid is commonly given to help decrease inflammation by mechanisms that are not completely understood.  



Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy showing friable mucosa with superficial ulcerations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies  :
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is another bile duct-related condition. It primarily affects middle-aged women, and individuals are typically positive for anti-mitochondrial antibodies. In contrast, this patient is p-ANCA positive and more likely has primary sclerosing cholangitis.
❌ Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound showing gallbladder wall thickening and edema:
Incorrect: Cholecystitis is due to inflammation of the gallbladder and presents with severe abdominal pain and fever. The chronicity of this patient’s symptoms and lack of abdominal tenderness makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Intestinal biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas and lymphoid aggregates:
Incorrect: Crohn disease results in noncaseating granuloma formation in the gastrointestinal tract. This patient has a history of bloody diarrhea, which may be consistent with Crohn disease. However, patients with Crohn disease are less likely to have p-ANCA antibodies or to have primary sclerosing cholangitis than those with ulcerative colitis.
❌ Positive anti-hepatitis A virus IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are seen in patients with acute hepatitis A. Hepatitis A typically results in acute jaundice as well as severe abdominal pain, nausea, and fever.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her friend after being found unconscious on the street. According to the friend, the patient has been drinking a liter of whiskey daily for the last 16 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 146/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice and palmar erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is mildly distended and mildly tender to palpation; there is a change in resonance from dull to tympanitic when the patient is moved from the supine to lateral decubitus position. With the patient in a supine position, a wave is produced by tapping one side of the abdomen. The liver is not palpable. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s abdominal findings?

choices.text: Elevated hepatic hydrostatic pressures due to splanchnic vasodilation
Backflow of blood into the vena cava inhibiting venous outflow from the liver
Hepatic vein obstruction resulting in venous congestion
Decreased intravascular osmotic pressure due to urinary excretion of protein
Accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
Portal hypertension plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of ascites in patients with liver cirrhosis. Portal hypertension triggers the release of vasodilators (e.g. nitric oxide), which leads to splanchnic and systemic vasodilation. This in turn decreases the effective circulating blood volume and activates vasoconstriction pathways, such as the renin-angiotensin–aldosterone system, leading to subsequent sodium and fluid retention. Over time, pressure in the portal vein increases, leading to an increase in the hydrostatic pressure within the hepatic vessels, and eventually, fluid is “squeezed” into the surrounding tissue. The end result is ascites formation.  

Diagnosis of ascites can often be done with a thorough physical examination. Shifting dullness refers to a change of resonance from dull to tympanitic when the patient changes from a supine to lateral decubitus position. A positive fluid wave test is signified by production of a wave by tapping one side of the abdomen; this wave will be transmitted to the other side of the abdomen through the ascitic fluid.



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated hepatic hydrostatic pressures due to splanchnic vasodilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Backflow of blood into the vena cava inhibiting venous outflow from the liver:
Incorrect: Right-sided heart failure is caused by impaired right ventricular function, and results in the backup of blood in the systemic circulation (e.g. vena cava, jugular veins) and portal venous system. The backup of blood would be unlikely to cause ascites alone, and her chronic alcohol use makes cirrhosis more likely to be the cause of her ascites.
❌ Hepatic vein obstruction resulting in venous congestion:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome occurs when the major hepatic veins are obstructed, resulting in liver enlargement, pain, and ascites. The condition can occur in pregnant women, patients with polycythemia, and patients with clotting disorders. This patient’s constellation of cirrhotic signs (e.g., jaundice, palmar erythema) and history of alcohol abuse makes Budd-Chiari syndrome less likely.
❌ Decreased intravascular osmotic pressure due to urinary excretion of protein:
Incorrect: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by renal loss of protein (>3.5 g/day), resulting in edema, hypercoagulability, and increased risk of infection. Loss of intravascular osmotic pressure can cause movement of water to the peritoneal cavity and result in ascites, such as in this patient. However, nephrotic syndrome would not account for the patient’s jaundice or palmar erythema.
❌ Accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity:
Incorrect: Acute pancreatitis results in the release of inflammatory cytokines and subsequent vascular injury by pancreatic enzymes. The injured vessels are more permeable to fluids and give rise to ascites. Pancreatitis, however, typically presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 20 weeks gestation comes to the physician due to abdominal discomfort and early satiety for the past few days. She denies headache, visual changes, cramping or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement is normal. Medical history is unremarkable. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a homogenous, well-demarcated, hyperechoic mass within the left lobe of the liver. A decision is made to follow up on the lesion post-partum. The follow-up ultrasound obtained 3 months after delivery shows an increase in the mass size without changes in the appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy pregnant woman most likely has a cavernous hemangioma.  

Cavernous hemangioma, also called hepatic hemangioma, is the most common benign tumor of the liver. Hemangiomas are tumors composed of large, dilated vascular channels that can arise throughout the body (e.g., liver, brain, eye). Their etiology is incompletely understood, but they are thought to arise from vascular malformations or hamartomas of congenital origin. A hemangioma can be diagnosed at any age but occurs most commonly in women between 30-50 years of age. Similar to adenomas, they tend to increase in size in response to estrogen exposure, but they can also occur in its absence. In contrast to hepatic adenoma, a cavernous hemangioma is unlikely to regress with estrogen withdrawal. Most tumors are asymptomatic and are often found as an incidental mass on imaging. When symptoms are present, right upper quadrant pain and abdominal fullness are common. Additional symptoms may include nausea, anorexia, and early satiety, due to compression of adjacent structures.  

Diagnosis is typically based on imaging, clinical presentation, and patient history. Ultrasound typically reveals a well-demarcated, hyperechoic, homogeneous mass. A biopsy is relatively contraindicated because of the risk of bleeding. Asymptomatic patients do not require treatment and are observed for the development of symptoms. When symptoms arise, surgery with resection or enucleation may be considered.    



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic adenoma:
Incorrect: Hepatic adenomas are rare, benign liver tumors arising from hepatocytes. The most common symptom is pain due to compression of adjacent structures. Hepatic adenomas tend to bleed and may result in life-threatening intra-abdominal bleeding. Hepatic adenomas carry some risk for malignant transformation. They have been associated with estrogen exposure (e.g. OCP and pregnancy). Although it is difficult to differentiate an adenoma from a hemangioma, the former often presents on ultrasound with central heterogeneous material and calcifications from bleeding. Also, adenomas are likely to regress in size with estrogen withdrawal, unlike this case.  
❌ Focal nodular hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Focal nodular hyperplasia, the second most common tumor of the liver, is thought to arise from a hyperplastic hepatocyte reaction to an underlying arteriovenous malformation. Ultrasound often shows a central scar, a highly suggestive finding for focal nodular hyperplasia.  
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary malignancy of the liver. Patients may present with jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, ascites, and anorexia. Risk factors include chronic hepatitis B or C infections, alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, autoimmune disease, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, and specific carcinogens (e.g. aflatoxin). On ultrasound, HCC typically presents with poorly-defined margins and coarse, irregular internal echoes. This patient has none of those risk factors and her imaging results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Cavernous hemangioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metastatic colon cancer:
Incorrect: Patients with any type of metastatic disease are likely to be more symptomatic from the primary cancer. Also, multiple hypoechoic lesions are typically seen on ultrasound, rather than a single hyperechoic mass.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of hematemesis. The patient appears disheveled and disoriented to time and place. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C infection. Abdominal examination shows distension with a fluid wave and protruding paraumbilical veins. Examination of the extremities reveals bilateral asterixis and 2+ edema in the bilateral lower extremities. A picture of his palms is shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely responsible for the appearance of this patient's palms?
questions.solution:
Liver cirrhosis leads to many clinical symptoms and signs related to the decreased synthetic capacity of the liver and progressive loss of liver functionality. This patient has several of the classic signs of decompensated liver disease including ascites and lower extremity edema due to hypoalbuminemia, asterixis and confusion due to hyperammonemia, and esophageal varices and caput medusae due to portal hypertension. The image of the patient’s palms demonstrates palmar erythema, which is due to hyperestrogenism.  

Given the loss of functional liver tissue, patients are unable to metabolize circulating estrogens through phase I (hydroxylation) and phase II (conjugation) pathways. As a result, there is increased circulating estrogen within the body. The increased estrogen is responsible for several clinical features of cirrhosis including palmar erythema, spider angiomas, gynecomastia, and testicular atrophy in men.  


Image reproduced from

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperammonemia:
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia is responsible for this patient’s altered mental status. In a healthy liver, ammonia is detoxified and metabolized into urea. Liver damage causes accumulation of ammonia, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and lead to diminished neuronal function.
❌ Hyperbilirubinemia:
Incorrect: Bilirubin is produced from heme breakdown. The liver takes up circulating bilirubin, conjugates it to increase water solubility, and excretes it in bile. Patients with liver disease will have reduced hepatic processing of bilirubin and can have jaundice. However, hyperbilirubinemia is not the cause of palmar erythema.
✅ Hyperestrogenism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoalbuminemia:
Incorrect: Albumin is produced in the liver and is the predominant protein in serum. It functions as a regulator of osmotic balance and transports a wide variety of molecules. Hypoalbuminemia causes a decrease in the intravascular oncotic pressure, resulting in fluid extravasation into the extravascular space. Low albumin can cause pedal edema and ascites, but not palmar erythema.
❌ Portal hypertension:
Incorrect: Portal hypertension occurs due to increased resistance within the hepatic sinusoids to portal venous blood flow. Collateral pathways subsequently open between the portal and systemic veins as a result of this increased pressure. This causes features such as esophageal varices, caput-medusae (protruding veins on the abdomen), hemorrhoids, and splenomegaly.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive upper abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. She states she has felt persistently nauseous over this time period and has vomited 5 times. Medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Examination reveals a patient in acute distress. Physical examination reveals yellow discoloration of the sclera. The abdomen is tender to palpation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness. No hepatomegaly is observed. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  17,000 mm3 
 Platelet count    240,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  87 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.8 g/dL 
 BUN  12 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   3.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.5 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase   190 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  210 U/L 
 Amylase  57 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   412 U/L 

Abdominal ultrasound shows dilation of the intra- and extrahepatic ducts. IV fluids and antibiotics are administered. Six hours later, the patient becomes disoriented. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Bacteria infiltrating into the biliary system
Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of biliary obstruction including fever, abdominal pain, jaundice (Charcot triad), and abnormal liver tests. Later, her condition deteriorates, as indicated by the hypotension and altered mental status (Reynolds pentad). She most likely has ascending cholangitis due to bacteria invading the biliary system.  

Ascending cholangitis, also known as acute cholangitis, is an inflammation of the biliary system, usually due to bacterial infection ascending from the duodenum. Most cases occur secondary to partial obstruction of the bile duct by gallstones, which disrupts normal barrier mechanisms. It can also occur following gastrointestinal surgeries involving biliary tract manipulation (e.g., biliary cyst removal, endoscopic sphincterotomy, biliary stent insertion). Laboratory tests typically reveal leukocytosis and a cholestatic pattern of liver test abnormalities (e.g., elevations in the serum alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and mainly, conjugated bilirubin). Treatment consists of supportive care, antibiotics, and biliary drainage, usually via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).  

Diagnostic criteria
Evidence of systemic inflammation with one of the following:    
  • Fever and/or shaking chills.
  • Laboratory evidence of an inflammatory response (e.g., leukocytosis, elevated, CRP, etc). 
and both of the following:

  • Cholestasis evidence: Bilirubin ≥2 mg/dL or abnormal liver chemistries. 
  • Imaging showing biliary dilation or evidence of the underlying etiology (e.g., stricture, stone, or stent).

Option Analysis

❌ Biliary leak:
Incorrect: A biliary leak is a complication of bile duct injury, usually following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Patients often present with fever, abdominal pain and/or bilious ascites and signs of peritonitis. On abdominal imaging, a loculated collection in the gallbladder fossa or around the liver can be seen. This patient has not had any recent abdominal surgery.   
✅ Bacteria infiltrating into the biliary system :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obstruction of the cystic duct:
Incorrect: The obstruction of the cystic duct is a cause of acute cholecystitis. Patients with acute cholecystitis also present with fever and abdominal pain. However, cholecystitis will not manifest with significantly elevated bilirubin or alkaline phosphatase, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder. Additionally, abdominal imaging in acute cholecystitis will likely show a normal common bile duct, gallbladder wall thickening, free pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign.  
❌ Gallstone obstructing the pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones lodged in the biliary tract can trigger acute pancreatitis by obstruction of the flow from the pancreatic duct or by obstructing the ampulla of Vater. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the gallbladder without obstruction describes acalculous cholecystitis, an acute necroinflammatory disease of the gallbladder in the absence of gallstones. It is commonly seen in critically ill patients and is thought to occur due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia, which leads to a local inflammatory response of the gallbladder wall. This patient was previously healthy, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status. The patient is disoriented and unable to provide her history. Review of the electronic medical record reveals a history notable for alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C infection. She lost her insurance several years ago, and since then, she has not seen a physician. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg, and pulse of 71/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice of the skin. Abdominal exam reveals the following:  

 
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following laboratory findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has jaundice, scleral icterus, and ascites (as seen from the distended abdomen). Given her history of chronic alcohol use and hepatitis C, the most likely cause of her condition is liver cirrhosis.  

Liver cirrhosis, along with hepatitis, causes mixed hyperbilirubinemia, because these conditions impair both bilirubin conjugation and canalicular excretion of bile. In advanced cirrhosis, glucuronyl conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin and biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin are markedly impaired, and jaundice appears. This decrease in bilirubin conjugation and increase in systemic circulation of conjugated bilirubin due to impaired excretion results in a mixed hyperbilirubinemia. The concentration of bilirubin in serum, therefore, is a good prognostic marker for patients with decompensated liver cirrhosis.  



Option Analysis

❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑  Normal  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conditions that increase hemolysis, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency or hereditary spherocytosis, can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In addition, hemolysis causes increased quantities of hemoglobin to be released, much of which is excreted via urine. However, this patient most likely has liver cirrhosis, which causes elevations in both unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin levels.
✅  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑  ↑Normal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin Normal ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be caused by impaired bilirubin excretion or biliary tract obstruction. Potential causes range from Crigler-Najjar syndrome to primary sclerosing cholangitis. However, this patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and hepatitis C infection makes liver cirrhosis the most likely underlying etiology, and liver cirrhosis causes mixed hyperbilirubinemia.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin ↑ ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with mixed hyperbilirubinemia have elevated conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels. Potential causes are hepatitis and liver cirrhosis. However, neither condition causes increased erythrocyte hemolysis. Hence, urine hemoglobin would be normal in these individuals. 
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine hemoglobin Normal  Normal Normal:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are concerning for elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman at 32 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with malaise, fatigue, and fevers. She reports she arrived from Egypt last week to visit family here. She reports she is otherwise healthy, does not smoke, use illicit drugs, or consume alcohol. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated. She has never received blood products in the past. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 137/72 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


This patient is at risk of developing which of the following pathologic conditions?
questions.solution:
This pregnant patient in the third trimester who recently immigrated from a different country presents with fatigue, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and laboratory markers consistent with active infection with hepatitis E. Of the choices listed, hepatitis E carries the highest risk of developing fulminant hepatitis, especially in pregnant women.  

Hepatitis E is a member of the herpes virus family and is an overall rare form of hepatitis in developed countries. However, in certain parts of the world—India, Africa, Southeast Asia—the disease carries a significant burden of disease, causing nearly 20 million infections on a yearly basis. It is spread via fecal-oral transmission, usually through contaminated seafood or water, and carries a short incubation period. Prior to symptom onset, patients will typically have increased levels of HEV RNA but negative titers for anti-HEV (IgM). Once a patient develops symptoms, typically two weeks after exposure, they will develop anti-HEV (IgM) antibodies. Most patients experience full recovery and will develop anti-HEV (IgG antibodies). It is important to note that hepatitis E does not confer a carrier state.    

At risk patients include pregnant patients, especially those in the third trimester, as well as patients with underlying liver disease. In these individuals, infection with hepatitis E carries a high risk of developing fulminant hepatitis—which refers to massive necrosis of liver parenchyma and atrophy. Treatment is largely supportive, and there is currently no vaccine against hepatitis E.

Option Analysis

✅ Massive necrosis of liver parenchyma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B, C, and D increase the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, while hepatitis E does not.
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscess is a rare entity associated with underlying liver or biliary disease or recent biliary tract manipulation. In developing countries, these abscesses are more commonly caused by parasitic infections, whereas in the United States they are most commonly caused by bacterial infection. It does not typically present with marked elevations in liver enzymes.  
❌ Membranous glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Active hepatitis B carries an increased risk of developing membranous glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. However, this patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows antibodies for the hepatitis B surface antigen, indicating immunity.
❌ B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C carries an increased risk for developing B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, as well as ITP, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. This pregnant patient with no risk factors for acquiring hepatitis C (e.g., intravenous drug use, blood product recipient) is likely infected with a different hepatitis virus, as indicated by the viral panel.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to altered mental status. He is disoriented and unarousable, but his partner is able to provide medical information. The patient has not seen a physician in several years, but he has noticed increased abdominal distension and leg swelling in the last year. Past medical history is notable for IV drug use and chronic hepatitis C infection, which was diagnosed 30 years ago. However, the patient has not used intravenous drugs in over 10 years. Physical examination reveals gynecomastia and multiple spider angiomata. His abdomen is significantly distended, with visible paraumbilical veins; shifting dullness to percussion is present. Splenomegaly is noted. The patient has 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which set of laboratory findings is most consistent with this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of cirrhosis (e.g., gynecomastia, spider angiomata, splenomegaly) and altered mental status. He likely has hepatic encephalopathy due to underlying cirrhosis brought about by chronic hepatitis C infection.  

Cirrhosis is an irreversible condition caused by recurrent hepatocellular damage (e.g., alcohol intake, viral infection) and repair, ultimately resulting in diffuse fibrosis and impaired hepatic function. Prothrombin time (PT) is a measure of the extrinsic coagulation pathway; since coagulation factors of the extrinsic system are mainly synthesized by the liver, an abnormally elevated PT can indicate liver dysfunction.  

Additionally, since albumin, a major constituent of serum proteins, is exclusively made in the liver, cirrhosis and declining liver function can result in reduced total albumin. This change contributes to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and leads to fluid extravasation and peripheral edema.  

As the liver becomes fibrotic, blood flow through the organ is impaired, resulting in backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses and subsequent elevation of portal pressure. This phenomenon is termed portal hypertension and can manifest with engorged paraumbilical veins (caput medusae) and splenomegaly.  

In contrast, hepatic steatosis and acute hepatitis are milder conditions that can be reversed if the underlying trigger for hepatocellular injury is removed. Furthermore, these conditions do not typically present with abnormalities in clotting parameters or serum albumin levels.  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with acute hepatitis, since the synthetic function of the liver is mainly intact. However, this patient has gynecomastia, spider angiomata, pitting edema, and abdominal ascites, which are suggestive of liver failure due to cirrhosis. Patients with cirrhosis typically have elevated PT and decreased total protein levels due to impaired hepatic synthetic function.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings is not consistent with the patient’s underlying cirrhosis. The impaired synthetic function of the liver would cause a decrease in total serum proteins, not increase.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings is not consistent with the patient’s underlying cirrhosis; the impaired synthetic function of the liver would cause a decrease in total serum proteins, not increase. Additionally, this patient’s portal pressure is likely elevated given there is clinical evidence of portal hypertension (e.g., enlarged paraumbilical veins, splenomegaly).
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has clinical symptoms of liver cirrhosis and likely has impaired hepatic synthetic function. Given that the liver is involved in the synthesis of clotting factors and serum proteins (e.g. albumin), patients with cirrhosis will have an elevated PT and decreased total protein level.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to altered mental status for the last 2 days. According to her husband, the patient has become increasingly lethargic, disoriented, and agitated. The patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection that was diagnosed 14 years ago. She refused all treatment at that time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 104/74 mmHg. On examination, the patient is lethargic and oriented only to self. When her hands are outstretched in front of her and extended at the wrist, they exhibit a flapping tremor. The abdomen is nontender and mildly distended; shifting dullness to percussion is present. There is no nuchal rigidity. Stool occult blood is positive. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:



The patient is started on emergent therapy for her symptoms. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Increased absorption of nitrogenous substances by the gut
Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms hepatic encephalopathy (e.g., asterixis, confusion, lethargy) in the setting of liver cirrhosis and an underlying gastrointestinal bleed, given the positive fecal occult blood test. Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) occurs since liver dysfunction results in insufficient elimination and subsequent accumulation of metabolic products (e.g. ammonia). As ammonia accumulates, it is able to cross the blood-brain-barrier, resulting in astrocyte swelling, dysfunction, and impaired neurotransmitter synthesis.  

Anything that increases ammonia production or reabsorption in the gut can trigger HE. These include gastrointestinal bleeding, constipation, or infections. Decreased ammonia elimination via the kidneys can also be a trigger. Finally, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) used to treat portal hypertension can also be a trigger since ammonia-rich blood from the intestines bypasses the liver completely.  

Hepatic encephalopathy presents with symptoms like insomnia or hypersomnia, mood changes, along with confusion, and even coma in some cases. Asterixis, a flapping tremor of the hand that appears when the wrist is extended, is commonly seen.  

Treatment typically involves administering antibiotics (e.g. rifaximin) to kill ammonia-producing bacteria and lactulose to decrease ammonia absorption in the bowel. Lactulose is converted to lactic acid by colonic bacteria resulting in acidification of the intestinal environment, leading to increased conversion of ammonia (NH3) to ammonium (NH4+). Ammonium is non-absorbable by the intestines and therefore excreted via feces.





Option Analysis

✅ Increased absorption of nitrogenous substances by the gut:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial infection of the meninges:
Incorrect: Meningitis, which is caused by bacterial infection of the meninges, can also result in fever and altered mental status. However, meningitis characteristically causes neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity), along with photophobia, which this patient lacks.
❌ Inflammation of brain parenchyma:
Incorrect: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain parenchyma, and it typically presents with a prodromal phase of fever, headache, and altered mental status. Acute encephalitis can cause seizures and behavioral changes. However, encephalitis itself would not explain the jaundice, shifting dullness to percussion, and asterixis as seen in this patient.
❌ Microbial infection of ascitic fluid:
Incorrect: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an infection of the ascitic fluid that is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and varying degrees of altered mental status. However, this patient’s asterixis and occult blood in the stool is suggestive of a different inciting condition.
❌ Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A stroke involving the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would present as contralateral paralysis and sensory loss affecting primarily the lower extremities as well as urinary incontinence. However, this patient’s asterixis and occult blood in the stool is suggestive of a different inciting condition.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset colicky abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant that started 1 hour ago. She states she has been feeling nauseous for several hours since the pain started and has vomited twice. She has had several episodes of abdominal discomfort in the past, especially after consuming food. Medical history is significant for hypertriglyceridemia and obesity. Medications include fenofibrate. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Abdominal examination reveals inspiratory arrest during palpation of the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound shows a thickened gallbladder wall and exquisite tenderness when the probe is applied on the right upper quadrant. A diagnosis is made, and the patient receives pain medication and IV hydration. Two weeks later, the patient undergoes elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy which reveals multiple stones within the gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased activity of HMG-CoA reductase enzyme

questions.solution:
This female patient, who is multiparous and has obesity, is presenting with right upper abdominal pain, positive Murphy sign and a thickened gallbladder on abdominal ultrasound; she most likely has acute cholecystitis due to cholesterol gallstones.   

In classic cholecystitis, gallstones obstruct the cystic duct, leading to a buildup of pressure and inflammation of the gallbladder. The typical presentation of cholecystitis includes right upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and occasionally fever. On physical examination, patients may demonstrate a positive Murphy sign, which is sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ. Similarly, a positive sonographic Murphy sign can be elicited with an ultrasound probe. Risk factors for cholesterol gallstones include female sex, pregnancy and oral contraceptive pills, obesity, and age, especially after 40. These can be remembered by the 4 F’s: female, fertile, fat, and forty.  

Bile production is the main pathway for elimination of excess cholesterol from the body, either as  bile salts or as free cholesterol. Cholesterol is secreted by the liver into the gallbladder and is rendered water-soluble within the bile by lecithins and bile salts. When cholesterol concentrations exceed the capacity of bile to solubilize it (supersaturation), cholesterol crystallizes and forms stones. Any condition that increases cholesterol and/or bilirubin, decreases bile salts, or promotes gallbladder stasis can cause gallstone formation. The enzyme 7α-hydroxylase converts cholesterol to 7-alpha-hydroxycholesterol, the rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis. Inhibition of this enzyme (e.g. by fibrates medication) can lead to the building up of cholesterol, its supersaturation, and stone formation.  

There are 2 types of stones, cholesterol stones (80% of cases) and pigment stones (black and brown). Cholesterol stones are associated with obesity, Crohn disease, advanced age, estrogen therapy, multiparity, and rapid weight loss.
