Option Analysis

❌ Decreased activity of HMG-CoA reductase enzyme:
Incorrect: HMG-CoA reductase is the enzyme responsible for the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate. Inhibition of this enzyme, such as by a statin, will result in decreased production of cholesterol and subsequently decreased risk for cholesterol gallstones.     
❌ Decreased activity of aromatase enzyme:
Incorrect: Aromatase is the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of androgen to estrogen. Increased level of estrogen increases the risk for cholesterol gallstones by increasing the hepatic secretion of biliary cholesterol. Therefore, decreased activity aromatase will reduce the risk for gallstones.   
✅ Decreased activity of 7α-hydroxylase enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased activity of β-glucuronidase enzyme  :
Incorrect: β-glucuronidase is a brush border enzyme that converts conjugated bilirubin to an unconjugated form for reabsorption. Any process that results in increased unconjugated bilirubin in the bile will increase the potential for pigment gallstone formation. However, this patient, who is multiparous and has obesity, is much more likely to have cholesterol gallstones, rather than pigment gallstones.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to a follow-up appointment following hospitalization due to diverticulitis. Since then, she has been recovering well and has no complaints. Medical history is significant for cholelithiasis, hypercholesterolemia, diverticulitis and constipation. Medications include statins, multivitamins, and supplemental fiber. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nontender, and bowel sounds are present. A CT obtained at the recent hospitalization is shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This woman who is currently asymptomatic has an incidental finding on CT scan showing calcification of the gallbladder (indicated by the red arrow), suggestive of porcelain gallbladder.  

Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder from chronic gallbladder inflammation. Approximately 95% of patients have associated gallstones. Patients with a porcelain gallbladder are usually asymptomatic, and the diagnosis is made incidentally on abdominal imaging. Occasionally patients can present with symptoms related to gallstones, including right upper quadrant/epigastric abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. On physical examination, the gallbladder may be palpable as a firm, non-tender mass in the right upper quadrant. Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a relatively increased risk for gallbladder cancer, mostly adenocarcinoma. However, since the absolute risk of developing cancer is low, some experts prefer observation, while others recommended elective cholecystectomy.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the liver in adults. It is associated with hepatitis B or hepatitis C chronic infection, other conditions of cirrhosis (e.g., alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, autoimmune diseases), and certain carcinogens (e.g., Aspergillus aflatoxin). Clinical findings include jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, ascites, polycythemia (due to excessive erythropoietin production), and anorexia. This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.  
❌ Budd-Chiari syndrome:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome is caused by thrombosis or compression of hepatic veins followed by centrilobular congestion and necrosis. Patients present with symptoms of congestive liver disease, such as hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, varices, ascites, and liver failure. It is associated with hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia vera, pregnancy, hepatocellular carcinoma). This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.  
❌ Liver cirrhosis:
Incorrect: Liver cirrhosis is a condition in which the liver loses its normal function due to long term damage and scarring (fibrosis). This damage is characterized by the replacement of healthy liver tissue with scar tissue. Etiologies include nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, chronic alcohol use, chronic viral hepatitis, biliary disease, autoimmune hepatitis, and genetic/metabolic disorders. This patient has none of these risk factors.  
✅ Gallbladder adenocarcinoma  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Primary biliary cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune chronic liver disease resulting from progressive destruction of the intrahepatic bile ducts of the liver. It is associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, Hashimoto thyroiditis, celiac disease). Common symptoms are fatigue, itching, and jaundice. This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to acute onset of abdominal pain, intense sweating, and vomiting. The pain is sharp, constant, 8/10 in intensity and radiates to the right shoulder blade. The patient has 2 children who were both delivered by cesarean section. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and obesity. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 37 kg/m2. ECG shows no abnormalities. An abdominal ultrasound is inconclusive due to body habitus. Further testing is performed, and the laboratory results are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000 mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  85 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  15 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  17 U/L 
 Amylase  50 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   60 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with abdominal pain that radiates to the right shoulder, vomiting and normal laboratory values most likely has biliary colic. Note that this patient has multiple risk factors for developing gallstones, including female sex, age, multiparity, and obesity.  

Biliary colic refers to episodic pain caused by temporary obstruction of the cystic duct by stone during gallbladder contraction. Common presentations include epigastric/right upper quadrant pain which may radiate to the right shoulder. The pain is often associated with diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting. Following a fatty meal (although it can happen after any meal), neurohormonal activation with cholecystokinin triggers the contraction of the gallbladder, forcing the stone into the cystic duct. When the contractions subside, the stone is displaced from the duct, relieving the obstruction. Biliary colic is a misnomer because the pain is usually constant and not colicky. The pain of biliary colic usually lasts less than 6 hours, compared to cholecystitis which is usually longer. Note that a fever will not be present in biliary colic, since there is no inflammatory process occurring, unlike in cholecystitis.  

During an episode of biliary colic, laboratory values should demonstrate normal values; this is because there is no inflammatory process occurring (unlike in cholecystitis), and therefore, no enzymatic markers should be elevated. Diagnosis is usually clinical and abdominal ultrasound may show stones within the gallbladder. Patients with repeated bouts of biliary colic are candidates for elective cholecystectomy after the pain subsides.    



Option Analysis

❌ Cholangitis:
Incorrect: Acute cholangitis is an inflammation of the biliary system secondary to partial obstruction of the bile duct by gallstones. Patients typically present with systemic signs, such as fever. Laboratory tests typically reveal leukocytosis and a cholestatic pattern of liver test abnormalities (i.e., elevations in the serum alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and mainly, conjugated bilirubin). This patient has no fever and has normal laboratory values, suggesting a different diagnosis.   
❌ Gallstone pancreatitis :
Incorrect: Gallstones lodged in the biliary tract can trigger acute pancreatitis by obstruction of the flow from the pancreatic duct or by obstructing the ampulla of Vater. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient has normal enzyme levels, favoring another diagnosis.   
✅ Biliary colic :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acalculous cholecystitis :
Incorrect: Acalculous cholecystitis is defined as inflammation of the gallbladder without evidence of gallstones or cystic duct obstruction. It is typically seen in critically ill patients due to gallbladder stasis. This patient is relatively healthy and has normal enzyme levels. 
❌ Calculous cholecystitis :
Incorrect: Calculous cholecystitis refers to the inflammation of the gallbladder due to cystic duct obstruction by stone. Typical presentation includes steady, severe epigastric or right upper quadrant pain which may radiate to the right shoulder or back. The pain is often associated with fever, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis but normal total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels, if the disease is limited to the gallbladder (uncomplicated cholecystitis).

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic with worsening abdominal pain and associated fatigue, intermittent nausea and vomiting, and dark urine. He reports his symptoms started three weeks ago and have not improved. He uses intravenous heroin and reports drinking approximately 4-6 beers daily. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a disheveled male with track marks noted in the antecubital fossa of the arms bilaterally. There is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory findings are as follows:  


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, malaise, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. The liver function tests demonstrate a marked elevation in ALT and AST concerning for acute hepatitis. Given the history of intravenous drug use and the relative increase in ALT compared to AST, this presentation is most consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis B.  

Viral hepatitis refers to either an acute or chronic infection of the liver caused by hepatitis viruses A, B, C, D, or E. Acute viral hepatitis is almost exclusively caused by hepatitis A or B, but it can be caused by the other hepatitis viruses as well. Acute viral hepatitis manifests with malaise, fever, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and dark urine within six months of infection. It will typically present with significant elevations in ALT and AST, usually on the order of >15 times the upper limit of normal with associated indirect hyperbilirubinemia.  

In contrast, chronic hepatitis is associated with hepatitis B and C and is most often asymptomatic but can progress to cirrhosis and end-stage liver disease. When symptoms do develop they are often constitutional and include features such as malaise or fatigue. Sometimes, the only features of infection may be cirrhotic liver disease, manifesting with jaundice, ascites, or spider angioma. Chronic hepatitis will also have elevations in liver enzymes, usually on the order of ~15 times the upper limit of normal.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acute hepatitis B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HIV:
Incorrect: Early HIV infection can manifest with non-specific viral symptoms including fatigue, malaise and low-grade fevers. It does not typically cause marked elevations in liver function tests or right upper quadrant tenderness.
❌ Biliary colic:
Incorrect: Biliary colic results from intermittent obstructing cholelithiasis. It can cause episodic right upper quadrant pain but does not typically cause elevation in liver enzymes.
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscess is a rare entity associated with underlying liver disease or recent biliary tract manipulation. In developing countries, pyogenic liver abscesses are more commonly caused by parasitic infections, whereas in the United States they are commonly caused by bacterial infections.
❌ Acute alcoholic hepatitis:
Incorrect: While this patient is a heavy user of alcohol, his liver function tests demonstrate an ALT>AST, consistent with a viral hepatitis pattern. Alcohol, as a mitochondrial poison, tends to generate an AST:ALT of approximately 2:1.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of fatigue, which began six months ago. He has felt more tired than usual and has had decreased libido over the same time period. The patient attributes these symptoms to recent stress at work as an attorney. Past medical history is noncontributory and he does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation of the skin. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Mild testicular atrophy is noted. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  



If untreated, this patient’s condition would most likely give rise to which of the following liver findings?

choices.text: Liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels
Iron-deficiency anemia and altered stooling habits
Multiple pulmonary nodules on chest CT scan
Demyelination of the dorsal columns and personality changes

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, hepatomegaly, hypothyroidism, skin hyperpigmentation, and elevated glucose levels. He likely has underlying hemochromatosis. If untreated, the condition can give rise to hepatocellular carcinoma, which manifests as a liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels.  

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the HFE gene that lead to increased iron absorption in the small intestine. Hemochromatosis is mostly asymptomatic early in life, but as toxic levels of iron accumulate in the body, it can become symptomatic, usually between the 3rd and 5th decade of life.  

The various organs that iron deposits in correlate with the clinical features of the disease: pancreatic accumulation leads to diabetes mellitus, dermal deposition results in hyperpigmented and bronze skin, pituitary damage causes decreased libido and testicular atrophy, joint deposition leads to arthralgias, thyroid deposition leads to hypothyroidism, and hepatic deposition results in hepatomegaly with eventual cirrhosis. The risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with hemochromatosis is up to 200 times higher than the general population. In fact, HCC causes nearly 50% of deaths in patients with hemochromatosis. HCC typically presents as weight loss, cachexia, a liver nodule, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Iron-deficiency anemia and altered stooling habits:
Incorrect: Iron-deficiency anemia and change in stools can result from a colonic mass (e.g. colon cancer), especially in adults over the age of 50. This patient’s underlying diagnosis, however, is more commonly associated with a different malignancy.
❌ Multiple pulmonary nodules on chest CT scan:
Incorrect: Multiple pulmonary nodules on CT scan could be indicative of a primary lung malignancy or metastases from a different organ. However, this patient does not smoke and has no symptoms of underlying pulmonary disease (e.g., dyspnea, chronic cough, hemoptysis). Instead, his symptoms of skin hyperpigmentation, hyperglycemia, and decreased libido are more concerning for hemochromatosis, which predisposes individuals to hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Demyelination of the dorsal columns and personality changes:
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis and cognitive impairment are commonly seen in tertiary syphilis (neurosyphilis). This patient has no risk factors for syphilis, and lacks previous symptoms associated with syphilis, such as a painless ulcer on the genitals (primary syphilis) or maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles (secondary syphilis).
❌ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of thyroid tissue:
Incorrect: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid tissue can develop in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient has signs and laboratory values consistent with hypothyroidism, his other symptoms (e.g., hyperglycemia, skin hyperpigmentation, testicular atrophy) cannot be fully explained by autoimmune thyroiditis alone.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after a 2-day history of abdominal pain, fever, and altered mental status. He is oriented only to self and is unable to name the city in which he lives or the current year. The patient has a history of chronic alcohol use and was found to have cirrhosis several years ago. His other medical conditions include hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice and palmar erythema. The abdomen is tense, distended, and tender to palpation. Shifting dullness to percussion is present. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient with alcoholic liver cirrhosis and ascites (e.g., distended abdomen, shifting dullness), is presenting acutely with abdominal pain, fever, and altered mental status. He likely has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).  

Ascites form due to a combination of portal hypertension, splanchnic vasodilation, and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. These factors contribute to water retention and overflow into the peritoneal cavity. Intestinal Gram-negative flora (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella) are able to translocate through the intestinal wall into the ascitic fluid, thereby causing SBP.  

Diagnosis is established by paracentesis and subsequent examination of the ascitic fluid for white blood cells, especially polymorphonuclear cells (neutrophils). By definition, SBP can be diagnosed when there are >250 PMNs/µL in the ascitic fluid. Treatment is typically with 3rd generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime).  






Option Analysis

✅ Microbial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial infection of the meninges:
Incorrect: Meningitis, which is caused by bacterial infection of the meninges, can also result in fever and altered mental status. However, meningitis characteristically causes neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity), along with photophobia, which this patient lacks.
❌ Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A stroke involving the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would present as contralateral paralysis and sensory loss affecting primarily the lower extremities as well as urinary incontinence. Although this patient has the risk factors for stroke (e.g., hypertension, T2DM), he lacks the associated motor deficits.
❌ Inflammation of brain parenchyma:
Incorrect: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain parenchyma, and it typically presents with a prodromal phase of fever, headache, and altered mental status. Acute encephalitis can cause seizures and behavioral changes. However, encephalitis itself would not explain the jaundice, palmar erythema, shifting dullness to percussion, and abdominal tenderness noted on physical examination.
❌ Infection of lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: Pneumonia is due to microbial infection of lung parenchyma, and classically presents with high fevers, cough (usually productive), dyspnea, and altered mental status if severe. This patient lacks a cough, and the presence of a distended, tender abdomen with shifting dullness makes another etiology more likely.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 3, is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain that started 3 hours ago. She describes the pain as sharp, constant, and rates it as 7/10 in intensity. Since the pain started, she has been feeling nauseous and has vomited twice. She reports a few episodes of similar abdominal discomfort in the past but says that this time it “feels different.” Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m2. The patient is in acute distress due to pain and points to the upper abdomen. The abdomen is tender to touch. No rebound tenderness or hepatomegaly is present. An abdominal ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  15,000 mm3 
 Platelet count    250,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  90 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.8 g/dL 
 BUN  11 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase   18 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase   20 U/L 
 Amylase  55 U/L 
 Lipase  62 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   65 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (right upper quadrant pain, nausea and vomiting), laboratory findings (leukocytosis, normal liver enzymes), and results of the abdominal ultrasound are suggestive of calculous cholecystitis.   

Acute calculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder, triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis. Marked elevation in the serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations are not common in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder (mild elevations may be present, however).  

Diagnosis relies on a transabdominal ultrasound that helps to visualize the gallbladder. Typical findings in acute cholecystitis include a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory arrest upon placing the ultrasound probe directly on the gallbladder), gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic free fluid around the gallbladder). If an ultrasound is inconclusive, a HIDA scan (cholescintigraphy) can be performed, in which a radioactive tracer is injected intravenously; normally, the radioactive tracer would fill the gallbladder, but in cases of cystic duct obstruction, the gallbladder would not be visualized.  

Option Analysis

❌ Choledocholithiasis :
Incorrect: Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones obstructing the common bile duct. Symptoms of choledocholithiasis include right upper quadrant (RUQ) or epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes jaundice; however, the systemic symptoms and signs seen in this patient (e.g., fever, leukocytosis) would not be seen. Instead, laboratory results may show elevation of ALP, GGT, direct bilirubin, and/or AST/ALT. Additionally, ultrasound of the RUQ in choledocholithasis typically shows dilated biliary ducts.   
❌ Pancreatitis :
Incorrect: Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.    
✅ Calculous cholecystitis :
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Appendicitis :
Incorrect: Appendicitis is an acute inflammation of the appendix caused by either obstruction from a fecalith (in adults) or lymphoid hyperplasia (in children). Patients usually present with fever, abdominal pain around the umbilicus/right lower quadrant, and nausea. If perforation occurs, peritoneal signs will be seen (e.g., guarding, rebound tenderness). This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Gallstone ileus:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a cause of bowel obstruction due to gallstones that enter the intestines through a cholecystoenteric fistula. It occurs secondary to cholecystitis leading to adhesion of the gallbladder to its surroundings and formation of a fistula between the gallbladder and intestine. Patients often present with intermittent abdominal pain, persistent nausea and vomiting, hematemesis and hyperactive bowel sounds. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with malaise and fatigue. She reports that several months ago, she had an influenza-like illness where she had low-grade fevers, chills, nausea, and vomiting that self-resolved. She reports since that event, she has not felt back to her normal self. She reports she is otherwise healthy and does not use illicit drugs, drink alcohol, or smoke tobacco products. She works as a nurse in a large healthcare facility and recently traveled to Haiti for a medical mission trip. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 132/72 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. She has screening labs performed which are notable for an ALT of 342 U/L and an AST of 221 U/L. She subsequently undergoes a liver biopsy which demonstrates lymphoid aggregates and areas of macrovesicular steatosis. This patient's clinical presentation was most likely the result of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This healthcare professional presents with malaise, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, and a liver biopsy consistent with hepatitis C infection. Of the answer choices listed, hepatitis C is primarily transmitted parenterally, such as through a needlestick injury.  

Hepatitis C is an enveloped single-stranded RNA flavivirus that is primarily transmitted parenterally (e.g., through needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions). Transmission through blood transfusion used to be a common cause, but due to improved routine screening of blood products, most acquisition now occurs through intravenous drug use.  

Compared to other forms of viral hepatitis, hepatitis C carries a long incubation period, usually on the order of two weeks to six months. Acute infection is typically mild and manifests with malaise, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, low-grade fevers, as well as nausea and vomiting. Chronic infection can be insidious, with the majority of patients experiencing no symptoms until cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma ensues. At this stage of infection, patients may manifest with features such as ascites, jaundice, coagulopathy, and hepatic encephalopathy.  

Clues to diagnosis are often reliant upon risk factors, such as being a healthcare worker or a dialysis patient. Histologically, the disease manifests with lymphoid aggregates and areas of macrovesicular steatosis on liver biopsy, as the virus can replicate in both hepatocytes and lymphocytes.

Option Analysis

✅ Needlestick injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Consumption of raw seafood:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the fecal-oral route, whereas hepatitis C is transmitted via needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions. Hepatitis A, while a potential cause of hepatitis in this patient who recently traveled to an endemic region, would typically present with an acute phase (e.g., fevers, nausea, vomiting) with elevated liver enzymes and a return to baseline following resolution. The chronicity of this patient’s condition raises concern for another hepatitis virus.
❌ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and D are transmitted sexually. Hepatitis C has also been documented to occur through sexual intercourse; however, sexual transmission is much less common than parenteral transmission.
❌ Vertical transmission:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and D can be transmitted vertically from mother to child during pregnancy. Hepatitis C has also been documented to occur through vertical transmission; however, vertical transmission is much less common than parenteral transmission.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: None of the hepatitis viruses are transmitted via vectors such as mosquitos.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the office by her partner due to hand tremors and a clumsy gait, which have progressively worsened over the last 4 months. Past medical history is noncontributory. She lives with her partner, who has noticed that she has become more withdrawn lately. The patient does not drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her BMI is 20 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. During the physical examination, the patient exhibits a flat affect while speaking. Her liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is mildly tender. No palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites is noted. A resting tremor is present in the bilateral hands. Further physical examination of this patient would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Green-brown rings in the periphery of the iris
Cool, dry skin and hair loss

questions.solution:
This young female has personality changes, tremors, and hepatomegaly and Kayser-Fleischer rings. These findings are suggestive of Wilson disease.  

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to impaired copper excretion into the bile and subsequent copper accumulation. Normally, the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13 encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. The protein helps excrete copper into the bile and synthesize ceruloplasmin (carrier protein for copper in the serum). However, these functions are impaired in patients with mutant copies of the gene.  

Initially, copper accumulates in the liver, manifesting as hepatitis, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. With disease progression, copper accumulates in other organs as well, such as the brain and cornea. Accumulation in the brain causes extrapyramidal symptoms, such as dysarthria, Parkinsonism (e.g. hand tremors), drooling, and behavioral changes (e.g. depression). Corneal deposition results in Kayser-Fleischer rings, which is a pathognomonic finding for Wilson disease. These green-brown rings are located in the periphery of the iris and can be visualized on slit-lamp examination.  

Laboratory testing may reveal reduced ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion. Treatment consists of chelating agents, such as penicillamine, which increase renal excretion of copper by forming water-soluble compounds.


Image reproduced from



Option Analysis

✅ Green-brown rings in the periphery of the iris:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperresonant lungs on percussion:
Incorrect: α1-antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by uninhibited neutrophil elastase activity, which results in destruction of lung parenchyma and panacinar emphysema. It would clinically manifest as hyperresonant lungs on percussion. Although the accumulation of misfolded α1-antitrypsin protein within hepatocytes can cause hepatocyte destruction and eventually cirrhosis, it would not present with the neurological disturbances seen in this patient.
❌ Diffusely hyperpigmented skin:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is caused by a genetic mutation resulting in uninhibited small intestinal reabsorption of iron. Over time, the iron accumulates, resulting in widespread deposition into organ tissues. Dermal deposition can present as diffuse hyperpigmentation (bronzing) of the skin. Although hemochromatosis can cause hepatitis and eventually cirrhosis, it would not present with the neurologic manifestations seen in this patient.
❌ Cool, dry skin and hair loss:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis results in iron deposition within various organs. Pituitary deposition can result in hypopituitarism, which can cause secondary hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism can cause cool, dry skin, hair loss, and fatigue. However, it would not lead to a hand tremor or abnormal gait.
❌ Exaggerated startle response:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative condition caused by misfolded protein particles (prions). Accumulation of prion particles in the brain eventually leads to neuronal degeneration. CJD presents with rapidly progressing dementia, depression, and an exaggerated startle response with myoclonus. It would not, however, present with hepatomegaly, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to his physician for evaluation of personality changes. At work, he has recently gotten into several heated arguments with colleagues and has missed several deadlines. The patient states, “I just feel more irritable than usual, and even small things get me angry." He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Medical history is notable for a right humeral fracture that occurred 5 years ago while playing soccer. Family history is notable for “liver disease” in his maternal uncle and grandfather, but he is unaware of additional details. Physical examination reveals greenish-brown rings around the iris. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Resting tremors are present in the bilateral hands. Which of the following sets of laboratory values would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has changes in personality, hepatomegaly, Kayser-Fleischer rings, and tremors. In combination, these findings are concerning for Wilson disease.  

Patients with Wilson disease have impaired biliary copper excretion and impaired hepatic incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that is heavily involved in copper transport throughout the body; 90% of copper is bound to ceruloplasmin whereas only 10% is free in the serum. As a result, patients with Wilson disease will have a decreased total serum copper concentration due to decreased ceruloplasmin levels. However, due to copper-overload, there is an increase in free serum copper (i.e. copper not bound to ceruloplasmin). The elevation in free serum copper subsequently leads to increased urinary copper excretion.  

Clinically, symptoms develop due to copper accumulation in various organs. Copper deposition in the liver can cause hepatotoxicity and cirrhosis. The excess copper also deposits in the brain causing Parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms. Disease progression can be slowed by administering copper chelating agents, such as penicillamine or trientine.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Total serum copper would be decreased, not increased, in patients with Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin, as seen in Wilson disease, leads to a decreased total serum copper.
❌ :
Incorrect: Total serum copper is decreased, not increased, in patients with Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin, as seen in Wilson disease, causes a decreased total serum copper. Furthermore, patients with Wilson disease have increased, not decreased, urinary copper excretion.
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms consistent with Wilson disease. Laboratory testing would reveal low ceruloplasmin levels. Furthermore, total serum copper would be decreased, not increased, in Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin leads to a decreased total serum copper.
❌ :
Incorrect: Patients with Wilson disease have reduced ceruloplasmin levels, which leads to an increase in free serum copper (copper not bound to ceruloplasmin). Since free serum copper is increased, urinary copper excretion would be increased as well.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to bloody vomiting. The patient was at home watching television when he felt nauseated and threw up “a cup full” of bright red blood. He has not experienced any chest pain. The patient has a history of hepatitis C infection that was diagnosed 7 years ago, but he was not treated due to a lack of medical follow-up. He has never consumed alcohol, but smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume illicit substances. At arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 98/64 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and palmar erythema. Paraumbilical veins are visible. There is 1+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. This patient’s condition is most likely related to which of the following?

choices.text: Infiltration of eosinophils in the esophagus

questions.solution:
Untreated hepatitis C infection is a common cause of liver cirrhosis, which can manifest with scleral icterus and jaundice, palmar erythema, caput medusae (visible paraumbilical veins), and fluid accumulation (e.g., pitting edema, abdominal ascites). As blood flow through the liver is impeded due to hepatic fibrosis and scarring, portal hypertension develops. There is subsequently backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses, as well as the spleen, which presents as splenomegaly. This increased backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses results in dilated veins. Prominent areas of anastomosis include the following:  

  • Anterior surface of the abdomen, causing caput medusae  
  • Lower rectum leading to hemorrhoids, which can manifest as hematochezia  
  • Lower end of the esophagus leading to esophageal varices  

Esophageal varices are at a major risk for rupturing and bleeding. Ruptured esophageal varices can cause massive hematemesis and life-threatening hemorrhage. Despite intervention, nearly 50% of patients die from their first bleeding episodes, and amongst those who survive, 20% have recurrent episodes.



Option Analysis

✅ Increased esophageal venous pressures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone:
Incorrect: Decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone can be seen in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which typically present as retrosternal burning pain (heartburn), regurgitation, and cough. However, GERD would not manifest with acute hematemesis.
❌ Rupture of the esophageal wall:
Incorrect: Transmural rupture of the esophageal wall is termed Boerhaave syndrome. It is rare but can occur after repeated episodes of vomiting or after prolonged coughing. Patients have severe retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (described as crepitus on chest auscultation), both of which this patient lacks.
❌ Infiltration of eosinophils in the esophagus:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by infiltration of eosinophils into the esophagus. It is associated with atopy and asthma. Patients can present with dysphagia and food impaction, but they usually do not have hematemesis. Additionally, this patient has symptoms of cirrhosis (e.g., scleral icterus, palmar erythema) and more likely has hematemesis secondary to an esophageal variceal bleed.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for a routine wellness visit. The patient has no acute complaints. However, he does recall having jaundice and abdominal pain 3 weeks ago, after completing a marathon. The symptoms self-resolved after a few days. Laboratory testing reveals a total bilirubin level of 4.8 mg/dL and a conjugated bilirubin level of 4.2 mg/dL. Urine testing is positive for elevated coproporphyrin I levels. Which of the following additional findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Dubin-Johnson syndrome, a benign genetic condition characterized by the absence of a biliary transport protein found on the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes. This transport protein is called multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2). As a result, less conjugated bilirubin is transported out of hepatocytes into the bile canaliculi. Eventually, this deficiency leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with total bilirubin levels between 2-5 mg/dL. Of note, in rare instances, individuals with this condition can develop elevated bilirubin levels ranging between 20-25 mg/dL.  

Most individuals are asymptomatic. However, some can develop mild jaundice during illness, pregnancy, after exercise, or after using certain medications (e.g. oral contraceptives). In addition, individuals can have nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, abdominal pain, and weakness.  

Patients will have elevated total and conjugated bilirubin levels with normal liver function tests. Urine testing will reveal high coproporphyrin I levels. Liver histopathology will show normal hepatocytes with lysosomes filled with a dense pigment composed of epinephrine metabolites. This buildup causes the liver to have a black appearance on gross examination. Note that in contrast, individuals with Rotor syndrome (a similar but milder condition) have normal urine coproporphyrin I levels and normal-colored livers.  

Option Analysis

❌ Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency:
Incorrect: Conditions that obstruct bile flow, such as gallstones or malignancies, can lead to this finding. However, this patient’s urine testing reveals elevated coproporphyrin levels, a finding suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Dubin-Johnson syndrome does not cause bile outflow obstruction or subsequent fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption.  
❌ Extraocular muscle palsy:
Incorrect: Extraocular muscle palsy is found in patients with kernicterus, which occurs when fat-soluble unconjugated bilirubin deposits in the brain and causes neurological sequelae. It typically occurs in patients with markedly elevated bilirubin levels. In contrast, this patient has mildly elevated bilirubin levels, and most of it is conjugated bilirubin, which is water-soluble and unlikely to deposit in the brain.   
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency or hereditary spherocytosis can develop splenomegaly. These conditions can cause jaundice secondary to increased erythrocyte hemolysis. However, this hemolysis would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Enlarged non-tender gallbladder:
Incorrect: This answer describes Courvoisier sign, which is an enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice. Courvoisier sign is found in patients with pancreatic cancer. However, it would be atypical for pancreatic cancer to cause intermittent jaundice or present in a young patient without risk factors (e.g., smoking, chronic alcohol use).  
✅ Blackened liver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 6-day-old female is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for evaluation of jaundice. She was born at 36 weeks gestation to a 29-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. According to her parents, the patient has had difficulty latching to her mother’s breast. The patient has passed meconium and produces 3-4 wet diapers per day. In the office, she is fussy but consolable. Physical examination shows depressed anterior and posterior fontanelles. Scleral icterus and jaundice of the head and chest are observed. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired conjugation of bilirubin in the liver
Extrahepatic fibrosis of the bile ducts
Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces

questions.solution:
This patient has breastfeeding failure jaundice, also termed starvation jaundice. It typically occurs during the first-week of life and is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. Therefore, there is increased enterohepatic circulation, ultimately causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Preterm babies are at increased risk of breastfeeding failure jaundice, since they may lack the strength and coordination to properly breastfeed. Patients with this condition can have jaundice, scleral icterus, and kernicterus in severe cases. In addition, the condition is associated with clinical features such as mild dehydration and weight loss in the first few days of life. As such, the patient in this vignette had sunken fontanelles and reduced urine output, both of which are signs of dehydration. Of note, a helpful tip in determining the number of wet diapers in the first week of life is that it is usually equivalent to the number of days since birth (e.g. a 6-day-old infant should produce 6 wet diapers/day).  

Treatment involves preventing dehydration and increasing the frequency and duration of feeds. All of these approaches help promote bilirubin excretion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased red blood cell turnover:
Incorrect: Newborns have higher rates of erythrocyte turnover when compared to adults. As a result, more hemoglobin is released and subsequently turned into unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, resulting in physiologic jaundice of the newborn. However, this patient has a history of poor breastfeeding and dehydration, which raises suspicion for breastfeeding failure jaundice.  
❌ Impaired conjugation of bilirubin in the liver:
Incorrect: Impaired conjugation of bilirubin by UDP-glucuronyl transferase can cause physiologic jaundice of the newborn. However, this patient has a history of difficulty breastfeeding and dehydration, which makes breastfeeding failure jaundice a more likely explanation for her symptoms.  
❌ Extrahepatic fibrosis of the bile ducts:
Incorrect: This answer describes biliary atresia, a condition wherein fibrosis results in destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Individuals can have jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, and hepatomegaly. Although this patient has jaundice, she has none of the other symptoms associated with biliary atresia.  
❌ Increased intestinal deconjugation of bilirubin:
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of breast milk jaundice. In this condition, the high levels of glucuronidase in breast milk deconjugates intestinal bilirubin, thereby increasing enterohepatic circulation of unconjugated bilirubin. However, the patient’s history of poor feeding and dehydration makes breastfeeding failure jaundice more likely.  
✅ Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to an infectious disease specialist after recently contracting a bloodborne pathogen. She uses intravenous drugs, and she became acutely ill with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting after using heroin several weeks ago. She has a past medical history of HIV and hepatitis B. Work up reveals she is currently infected with an RNA delta virus. Infection with this virus is dependent on the presence of which of the following cofactors in host cells?
questions.solution:
This patient who uses intravenous drugs and has a history of HIV and hepatitis B presents with a new infection with an RNA delta virus, consistent with hepatitis D infection. Hepatitis D, unlike other forms of viral hepatitis, requires co-infection with hepatitis B, since the virus is dependent on HBsAg for viral entry.  

Hepatitis D is an RNA delta virus that is transmitted sexually and parenterally; however, most cases occur via contamination with infected blood products. The virus is composed of a single strand of RNA, without cellular machinery to mediate its own replication and information encoding viral capsid proteins for its progeny. Therefore, the virus is completely dependent on the hepatitis B surface protein HBsAg for viral entry. If universal vaccination against hepatitis B were present, hepatitis D would have no portal for entry, since the vaccine generates antibodies against HBsAg.  

Often, co-infection with hepatitis B and D occurs at the same time, or it may occur at a later time in patients that are already chronic carriers of hepatitis B. In the latter case, a superinfection can result, which portends a worse prognosis in terms of developing cirrhosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ HBsAg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HBeAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis E antigen is an intracellular protein that is secreted by hepatitis B. It is not needed for viral entry by hepatitis D.
❌ gp120:
Incorrect: HIV uses the surface glycoprotein gp120 for docking onto host T-cells. It is not utilized in coinfection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.
❌ Neuraminidase:
Incorrect: Influenza virus utilizes neuraminidase, which cleaves glycosidic linkages of neuraminic acid and serves as an important virulence factor in the spread of influenza. It has no role in the co-infection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.
❌ E1 glycoprotein:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C utilizes two surface glycoproteins to mediate entry into the hepatocyte—E1 and E2. These glycoproteins have no role in the infection of hepatitis D virus, an RNA delta virus.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman at 23 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician for routine follow up. She recently underwent perinatal screening and tested positive for hepatitis B. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated, and she has no other significant past medical history. During the visit, the patient asks, “How likely is it that I am going to give this disease to my baby?” Her hepatitis panel is demonstrated below:

Which of the following serologic markers indicates a high degree of transmissibility to the fetus?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with serology consistent with chronic hepatitis B of high infectivity, as indicated by her positive serologic test for HBeAg. Of the serologic tests listed, a titer positive for HBeAg confers a high degree of transmissibility and viral replication.  

Multiple serologic tests are used in the diagnosis of hepatitis B infection including: HBsAg, anti-HBs, HBcAg, anti-HBc, HBeAg, and anti-HBe. Hepatitis B s antigen (HBsAg) is a surface antigen that is most commonly used to indicate active infection. Once the body develops antibodies to HBsAg, termed anti-HBs, the patient is deemed recovered or to have complete immunity to the virus.  

The hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is an intracellular antigen that is expressed in infected hepatocytes and indicates active viral replication within hepatocytes. Anti-HBc comes in two distinct forms: IgM, which indicates acute infection or recent infection, and IgG, which indicates resolved or chronic infection.  

Hepatitis E antigen (HBeAg) is a secretory protein that is processed from the precore protein and is considered to be a marker of high HBV replication, infectivity, and transmissibility. The presence of HBeAg is associated with high levels of HBV DNA in serum and thus higher rates of transmission of HBV infection from carrier mothers to their babies and from patient to patient. Antibodies to this protein, deemed anti-HBe, indicate low infectivity.

Option Analysis

✅ HBeAg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HBsAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis B surface antigen is most commonly used to screen for evidence of active infection, and antibodies to this antigen indicate active immunity.
❌ HBcAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis B core antigen is another surface antigen like HBsAg that indicates active viral replication and that the infected person is currently infectious. It does not confer information regarding the degree to which a person is infectious.
❌ Anti-HAV (IgG):
Incorrect: Anti-HAV (IgG) indicates previous infection against hepatitis A. This test does not confer significant information regarding hepatitis B.
❌ Anti-HBc (IgG):
Incorrect: This serologic assay is used to detect for antibodies against HBcAg. IgG indicates that the immune system is mounting a response to a chronic infection.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic with fatigue and malaise. He reports he has been experiencing symptoms for over the past six months and wants to make sure he “hasn’t contracted a sexually transmitted infection.” He currently uses intravenous drugs and has had multiple sexual partners over the past year. He has no other significant past medical history. A screening HIV test is negative, and the remainder of the laboratory results are detailed below:


Which of the following best describes the replicative mechanism of the pathogen with which this patient is infected?

choices.text: Reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny
Reverse transcription of an RNA template into double-stranded DNA progeny
Use of an RNA dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded RNA progeny
Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize double-stranded DNA progeny
Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded DNA progeny.

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use and multiple sexual partners over the past year presents with six months of malaise and fatigue. The laboratory findings are consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection, and he is currently highly infectious given the positive HBeAg titer. Of the replicative mechanisms listed, reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny describes the replicative mechanism of hepatitis B.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. Following inoculation, hepatitis B infects hepatocytes via a bile salt transporter and utilizes cellular DNA polymerase to complete replication of the partially double-stranded (ds) segment of the virus. After this step, the virus uses host RNA polymerase to transcribe a single-stranded RNA template from the dsDNA genome for translation of the viral capsid, DNA polymerase/reverse transcriptase, and associated proteins. Finally, the virus utilizes this DNA polymerase/reverse transcriptase to generate partially dsDNA progeny.  

After infection, hepatitis B carries an incubation period of approximately 180 days, after which patients may experience a prodrome of symptoms such as malaise, arthralgias, fatigue, rash, or lymphadenopathy. Patients may then experience symptoms of acute hepatitis (jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) or have complete resolution and viral clearance. Other patients go on to develop chronic hepatitis or fulminant hepatitis, which is characterized by severe liver necrosis and atrophy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reverse transcription of an RNA template into double-stranded DNA progeny:
Incorrect: HIV utilizes a reverse transcriptase to synthesize dsDNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis  panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of an RNA dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded RNA progeny:
Incorrect: Picornaviridae and influenza viruses utilize this replicative mechanism to generate single-stranded RNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize double-stranded DNA progeny:
Incorrect: Herpes viruses utilize this mechanism to generate double-stranded DNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded DNA progeny.:
Incorrect: Parvovirus is the smallest DNA virus and utilizes this mechanism to generate single-stranded DNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was found unconscious in an alley by a bystander who called paramedics to the scene. Upon arrival in the emergency department, the patient is mumbling but is unable to report his medical history. Chart review demonstrates a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis B infection. Temperature is 36 °C (96.8°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 100/53 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates jaundice, track marks on the upper extremities, as well as diffuse ecchymosis. The patient is appropriately resuscitated, and the following laboratory results are seen:

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with infection with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hepatitis B and intravenous drug use presents with altered mental status and features concerning for fulminant hepatitis. Characteristic features include evidence of severe liver injury evidenced by jaundice, altered mental status, significant elevation of AST and ALT (>15 times the upper limit of normal) with signs of shock and coagulopathy (elevated PT and aPTT). Given this patient's history of chronic hepatitis B, this clinical presentation is suspicious for superinfection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.  

Hepatitis D is an RNA delta virus that is transmitted sexually and parenterally; however, most cases occur via contamination with infected blood products or contaminated syringes. The virus is completely dependent on the hepatitis B surface protein HBsAg for viral entry, and thus patients must either have a prior history of hepatitis B infection or undergo coinfection simultaneously with hepatitis B.  

Coinfection, where hepatitis B and hepatitis D are acquired at the same time, represents the most common mechanism of hepatitis D infection. Coinfection presents similarly to acute hepatitis B with malaise, arthralgias, fatigue, a rash, or lymphadenopathy occurring weeks to months after infection. Superinfection, such as in this patient, occurs when patients who are already chronic carriers of hepatitis B become infected with hepatitis D. This form of acquisition presents with a shorter incubation period, more severe symptoms of hepatitis, and significantly increases the risk of progression to fulminant hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.  

Diagnosis of hepatitis D infection is achieved by obtaining viral titers against the pathogen, and liver biopsy will demonstrate similar features to hepatitis B, with a ground glass appearance.   

Option Analysis

✅ RNA delta virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ RNA picornavirus:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A is spread via the fecal oral route and is an extremely uncommon cause of fulminant hepatitis. Most cases are mild and self resolve without hospitalization.
❌ RNA hepevirus:
Incorrect: Hepatitis E carries a risk of fulminant hepatitis in pregnant mothers in endemic areas. This patient with a history of hepatitis B and intravenous drug use more likely has a different cause for fulminant hepatitis.
❌ RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis C is a rare event, as most cases progress to stable chronic infection.
❌ RNA orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Influenza tends to present with abrupt onset of high fevers and rigors and does not typically cause severe symptoms in patients without significant comorbidities or an immunocompromised state.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic due to concerns for contracting a sexually transmitted infection. He reports that several months ago, he had unprotected sexual intercourse, and several weeks thereafter, he experienced malaise, fatigue, and jaundice. He reports since then, his symptoms have abated, but he is concerned because he started a new relationship and does not want to “potentially infect” his new partner. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:

Which of the following best describes the current clinical stage of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with serologic markers consistent with a recovered infection from hepatitis B, as indicated by the presence of antibodies to the surface antigen, core antigen, and e antigen. Given his recovered status, he is no longer considered infectious from hepatitis B.  

Multiple serologic markers are utilized in determining the stage of infection from hepatitis B. The first markers to rise in acute hepatitis B infection are HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibodies, oftentimes with positive HBeAg titers. Next is the window period, which is the time between first infection and when the test can reliably detect that infection occurs. During this period, the patient may be infected; however, viral titers are so low that the patient may have negative serological testing for HBsAg, HBcAg, or HBeAg. During this period, the only markers that are positive are either anti-HBc IgM or anti-HBe.  

Chronic infection is defined by the presence of HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG, +/- the presence of HBeAg. When HBeAg is present, this indicates a high degree of HBV replication, infectivity, and transmissibility. Recovery is then defined by antibodies to HBs, anti-HBc IgG, and anti-HBe. Immunized patients (e.g. vaccinated) can be differentiated as they possess only anti HBsAg antibodies.

Option Analysis

✅ Recovered:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic HBV with high infectivity:
Incorrect: Chronic HBV with high infectivity would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgG.
❌ Chronic HBV with low infectivity:
Incorrect: Chronic HBV with low infectivity would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, anti-HBe, and anti-HBc IgG.  
❌ Acute HBV:
Incorrect: Acute HBV would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM. Additionally, the patient would likely be symptomatic, as opposed to his already resolved symptoms.
❌ Window period:
Incorrect: The window period of hepatitis B infection is indicated by a positive anti-HBc IgM and anti-HBe titers.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with malaise, nausea, and vomiting. She reports onset of symptoms one week ago and states her condition has not been improving. She has no associated diarrhea or muscle aches, and she has not traveled recently. She does not use tobacco products, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is otherwise healthy and asks when she can go back to work at her daycare facility. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 15/min and blood pressure is 123/72 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus. Palpation of the right upper quadrant elicits significant pain. Which of the following types of vaccine could have prevented this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus

questions.solution:
This patient works at a daycare facility and presents with malaise, nausea, vomiting, and scleral icterus, concerning for infection with hepatitis A. Vaccination against hepatitis A is achieved using an inactivated form of the virus.  

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an RNA picornavirus that is transmitted via contaminated food or water and is the most common form of acute hepatitis. Risk factors for HAV transmission include residence in or travel to areas with poor sanitation, contact with another person with hepatitis A, and exposure to daycare centers. After inoculation, symptoms develop within anywhere from one week to thirty days and include malaise, fevers, jaundice, nausea, vomiting and right upper quadrant pain.  

Vaccination against hepatitis A is achieved with administration of an inactivated form of the picornavirus. Individuals who should undergo vaccination include those who are traveling or working in endemic areas, those with chronic liver disease, and men who have sex with men. Successful vaccination and immunity is substantiated by laboratory analysis demonstrating anti-HAV (IgG) antibodies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inactivated RNA picornavirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Live-attenuated RNA reovirus:
Incorrect: Rotavirus is a common pathogen amongst children and those who work closely with children (e.g. daycare workers). Rotavirus almost always presents with associated diarrhea, which this patient does not have.
❌ Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus:
Incorrect: The vaccine for hepatitis B is against the hepatitis B surface antigen. This patient who is otherwise healthy does not carry significant risk factors (e.g. intravenous drug use) for hepatitis B acquisition.
❌ Live-attenuated RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Yellow fever is a vector borne illness transmitted via the Aedes aegypti mosquito. This patient does not have risk factors for this illness such as recent travel to endemic areas.
❌ Inactivated RNA orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Influenza tends to present with abrupt onset of high fevers and rigors. While gastrointestinal symptoms can occur, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with acute hepatitis A infection.

A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with increasing abdominal girth. He reports he has gained approximately 6.8 kg (15-lb) over the past several weeks and has had difficulty passing stool. He reports he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He was born in India and is unsure if he was ever fully vaccinated. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. With the patient in a supine position, a wave is produced by tapping one side of the abdomen. Initial work up in the emergency department is notable for elevated liver enzymes and proteinuria. He is subsequently admitted and has the titers listed in the table below drawn the next day.

Which of the following indicates a poor prognosis for this disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms concerning for cirrhosis including jaundice and ascites. His workup reveals a hepatitis panel consistent with chronic hepatitis B with a high infectivity. Of the factors listed, high titers of HBeAg confer a poor prognosis.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. After infection, hepatitis B carries an incubation period of approximately 180 days, after which patients may experience a prodrome of symptoms such as malaise, arthralgias, fatigue, a rash, or lymphadenopathy. Patients may then experience symptoms of acute hepatitis (jaundice, right upper quadrant pain), have complete resolution and viral clearance, or progress to fulminant hepatitis characterized by severe liver necrosis and atrophy.  

However, many patients go on to develop chronic hepatitis, whereupon they act as carriers of the disease. Approximately 5% of infected adults, 20% of infected children, and 90% of infected neonates go on to develop chronic disease. In infected neonates, anti-hepatitis B immunoglobulin as well as an initial dose of HBV vaccine should be administered. Over time, chronic infection portends a risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, and patients with chronic infection are often treated with interferon alpha.  

Option Analysis

✅ High titers of HBeAg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Absence of anti-HBs-antibodies:
Incorrect: The absence of anti-HBs-antibodies indicates paucity of immunity to hepatitis B but does not relay information regarding prognosis.
❌ Adult age:
Incorrect: Adults have an overall higher rate of complete resolution of hepatitis B infection, in contrast to the extremes of age. In immunocompetent adults, the likelihood of progression to chronic HBV infection is less than 5 percent.
❌ High titers of HBcAg  :
Incorrect: HBcAg is reflective of high replication of hepatitis B but does not confer significant information regarding prognosis.
❌ Presence of extraintestinal manifestations:
Incorrect: The presence of extraintestinal manifestations may portend an increased risk of associated morbidity; however, it does not increase the overall risk of mortality.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to an infectious disease specialist for follow up regarding hepatitis B infection. He was recently diagnosed after having unprotected sexual intercourse. The patient has serological markers drawn over time and is currently at the point as indicated by the arrow on the graph below. Based on this information, this patient is at which stage of infection?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hepatitis B presents for follow-up regarding his current infectious state. Based on his serological studies as indicated in the graph above, he is currently in the window phase of infection—characterized by detectable levels of anti-HBe and anti-HBc IgM.  

Multiple serologic markers are utilized in determining the stage of infection from hepatitis B. The first markers to rise in acute hepatitis B infection are HBsAg and HBeAg, which is called the incubation period. Next, anti-HBc IgM antibodies rise along with continually rising HBeAg and HBsAg, termed the prodromal or acute infectious phase. Next, the window period occurs, which is when neither hepatitis B surface antigen nor its antibody can be detected in the serum of the patient due to the precipitation of antigen-antibody complexes and their removal from the circulation. During this period, the patient may be infected; however, viral titers are so low that the patient may have negative serological testing for HBsAg, HBcAg, or HBeAg. During this period, the only markers that are positive are either anti-HBc IgM or anti-HBe.  

Recovery is then characterized by detectable levels of anti-HBc IgG, anti-HBs, and anti-HBe. Chronic infection is defined by the presence of HBsAg, anti-Hbc IgG, +/- the presence of HBeAg. When HBeAg is present, this indicates a high degree of HBV replication, infectivity, and transmissibility. Recovery is then defined by antibodies to HBs, anti-HBc IgG, and anti-HBe. Immunized patients can be differentiated as they possess only anti-HBsAg antibodies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Window period:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Incubation  :
Incorrect: The incubation period is the time during which patients are generally asymptomatic and virions are undergoing replication. This phase is characterized by detectable levels of HBsAg and occasionally HBeAg between one to two months after exposure. 
❌ Acute disease:
Incorrect: Acute disease is characterized by detectable levels of HBsAg, HBeAg, as well as anti-HBc IgM, as denoted by the area in pink. During this period, patients are considered infectious and will have elevated liver function tests. Signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fever, dark urine, changes in stool color, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and jaundice. Extrahepatic manifestations of disease (e.g., skin rash, arthralgias, and arthritis) may also occur.
❌ Prodrome:
Incorrect: Like acute disease, the prodromal phase overlaps and is characterized by detectable levels of HBsAg, HBeAg, as well as anti-HBc IgM, as denoted by the area in pink. During this phase, patients may experience mild symptoms, such as malaise and anorexia, although they are usually not as severe as acute disease.
❌ Recovery:
Incorrect: Recovery is the period of infection characterized by detectable levels of anti-HBc IgG, anti-HBs, and anti-HBe.

A 56-year-old woman patient presents to an outpatient clinic with fatigue and malaise. She reports worsening malaise over the past several weeks and noted that her abdomen seems more protuberant. She regularly uses intravenous drugs but has not used in several weeks. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus and a positive fluid wave. Initial work up is notable for an ALT of 451 U/L and an AST of 321 U/L. The remainder of her laboratory findings are demonstrated below.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Chronic infection with an RNA flavivirus
Acute infection with an RNA flavivirus
Resolved infection with an RNA flavivirus
Chronic infection with a DNA hepadnavirus

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with malaise, fatigue, and laboratory findings consistent with recovery from hepatitis B and chronic HCV infection. Given the physical examination findings, there is concern this patient has ascites and likely underlying cirrhosis.  

Hepatitis C is an enveloped single-stranded RNA flavivirus that is primarily transmitted parenterally (e.g. through needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions). Screening labs for hepatitis C include liver function tests such as ALT and AST, which will generally be >15 times the upper limit of normal in acute infection and <15 times the upper limit of normal in chronic infections. Additionally, ALT will be greater than AST in the majority of patients with hepatitis C and viral hepatitis in general.  

Definitive testing for hepatitis C involves obtaining both a hepatitis C RNA titer and as well as an anti-HCV antibody titer. The following scenarios are possible:  
  • Patients with a positive hepatitis C RNA titer and negative anti-HCV antibody titer are said to have acute hepatitis C infection.  
  • Patients with both a positive hepatitis C RNA titer and positive anti-HCV antibody titer are said to have chronic hepatitis C infection.  
  • Patients with a negative hepatitis C RNA titer and a positive anti-HCV antibody titer are said to have recovered from hepatitis C. Importantly, recovered patients are not considered immune from subsequent infection due to substantial genetic diversity amongst serotypes.


Option Analysis

✅ Chronic infection with an RNA flavivirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute infection with an RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Acute infection with hepatitis C is most often asymptomatic, but in 20-30% of cases, it will present with malaise, fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine. Laboratory diagnosis of acute hepatitis C will often demonstrate positive hepatitis C RNA without the presence of antibodies.
❌ Resolved infection with an RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Resolved hepatitis C infection will demonstrate positive hepatitis C antibodies with negative hepatitis C RNA.
❌ Acute infection with DNA hepadnavirus:
Incorrect: Acute hepatitis B is difficult to distinguish clinically from acute hepatitis C. Laboratory findings in acute hepatitis B infection will demonstrate positive anti-HBc IgM and positive HBsAg.
❌ Chronic infection with a DNA hepadnavirus:
Incorrect: Chronic infection with hepatitis B is characterized by a positive HBsAg and anti-HBc IgG.
