A 37-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for a routine check up. She reports that she is otherwise feeling well but has noticed that her urine is darker than usual. She has had no recent diarrhea, weight loss, or muscle pain. Past medical history is unremarkable, but she states she was born in India to a mother with “some liver disease” at the time of her birth. She has a glass of wine every Sunday night with dinner. She does not smoke cigarettes or use other illicit substances. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:

Which of the following could have been used to prevent this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus and immunoglobulin
Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus

questions.solution:
This patient presents features concerning for hepatitis including dark urine (due to increased levels of conjugated bilirubin) and elevated liver function tests. Her past medical history is notable for a mother with a suspicious “liver disease” and potential vertical transmission of hepatitis B to the patient in question. Of the answer choices listed, the appropriate management for this patient at the time of birth would have been vaccination with hepatitis B in addition to administration of hepatitis B immune globulin.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. Approximately 95% of primary infections in immunocompetent adults are self-limited, with elimination of the virus from blood and generally immunity to reinfection. In contrast, chronic infection occurs among 80%–90% of neonates infected during infancy, 30% of persons infected before age 6 years, and <1%–12% of persons infected as an older child or adult; therefore, detection and intervention are absolutely crucial during the early neonatal period.  

Vaccination efforts using the subunit HBsAg in the developed world have dramatically reduced the incidence of hepatitis B infection. In the developing world, routine vaccination is still underway and many infants acquire the disease via vertical transmission. If a mother is a known carrier for hepatitis B, administration of both the vaccine and hepatitis B immune globulin reflects appropriate management. Patients with confirmed immunity to the disease will demonstrate appropriate titers of anti-HBsAg.   

Option Analysis

✅ Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus and immunoglobulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Live-attenuated RNA reovirus:
Incorrect: Rotavirus is a common pathogen amongst children and those who work closely with children (e.g. daycare workers). Rotavirus almost always presents with associated diarrhea, which this patient does not have.
❌ Subunit of a circular DNA hepadnavirus:
Incorrect: The vaccine for hepatitis B is against the hepatitis B surface antigen. In patients born to mothers with a known history of hepatitis B, both the vaccine and the immunoglobulin should be administered.
❌ Live-attenuated RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Yellow fever is a vector borne illness transmitted via the Aedes aegypti mosquito. This patient does not have risk factors for this illness such as recent travel to endemic areas.
❌ Inactivated RNA orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Influenza tends to present with abrupt onset of high fevers and rigors. While gastrointestinal symptoms can occur, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to an infectious disease physician after recently being diagnosed with hepatitis C. The patient acquired the pathogen after using shared syringes to inject intravenous heroin. The patient asks, “Is there any way this infection could have been prevented aside from abstaining from intravenous drug use?” The physician responds by stating vaccine development has been difficult due to this pathogen’s ability to evade the host immune system. Which of the following molecular mechanisms prevents the development of an effective vaccine against this virus?
questions.solution:
This patient has been infected parenterally with an RNA flavivirus, consistent with hepatitis C infection. Prevention of hepatitis C is achieved with public health measures including disposable syringe programs, screening at-risk individuals, and careful examination of blood products prior to transfusion. Unfortunately, the development of a vaccine against hepatitis C has proved exceedingly difficult due to large errors made during replication and subsequent development of quasispecies, which are a subset of the virus population with a large number of variant genomes due to increased rates of mutations.  

Hepatitis C has multiple genotypes (upwards of 6) with significant genetic variations. Once infected, the virus replicates inside of hepatocytes, where the virion encoded RNA-dependent RNA polymerase lacks 3’→5’ proofreading activity. This paucity of proofreading results in significant genetic differences amongst viral progeny and epitope differences in envelope glycoproteins, making it difficult for the adaptive immune system to suppress the virus or develop a vaccine.  

Option Analysis

✅ Faulty RNA proofreading activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antigenic shift:
Incorrect: Influenza viruses undergo a process termed antigenic shift, where two or more different strains of a virus, or strains of two or more different viruses, combine to form a new subtype having a mixture of the surface antigens of the two or more original strains.  
❌ Glycosylation of g120 epitopes:
Incorrect: One of the difficulties in generating an effective vaccine against HIV has been that gp120, a docking surface glycoprotein, is frequently masked by glycosylation. This process prevents effective neutralizing antibodies from targeting the virus.
❌ Large number of serotypes:
Incorrect: Effective vaccination against rhinovirus, which causes the common cold, has proven difficult due to over 160 different serotypes of the virus.
❌ Intracellular epitopes:
Incorrect: The targets of antibodies against hepatitis C are found on the cell surface, not intracellularly.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. He reports a progressive onset of symptoms over the past several weeks, and he has also noted the appearance of purplish, itchy, flat bumps on his forearms and legs. He also states his urine looks “darker” than usual. Past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus and intravenous heroin use in his 20s. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 134/72 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a cachectic male in no acute distress, with submandibular and axillary lymphadenopathy, violaceous papules on the arms and legs, and 1+ pitting edema. Urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein without blood. He subsequently undergoes lymph node biopsy, which demonstrates the following histologic image:


Reproduced from:

Which of the following pathogens is most likely associated with patients clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with constitutional B symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. The examination demonstrates diffuse lymphadenopathy, features of nephrotic syndrome, and lichen planus (“violaceous papules”). The lymph node biopsy demonstrated large, atypical B-cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio consistent with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Give the clinical manifestations in this patient, he should undergo evaluation for concurrent hepatitis C infection.  

Hepatitis C infection often presents with multiple extrahepatic manifestations including hematologic, autoimmune, renal, and dermatologic diseases. Oftentimes, these disease states are the only clinical features of the infection. Associated hematologic diseases include essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, ITP, autoimmune hemolytic anemia and leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Autoimmune conditions include diabetes, hypothyroidism and dermatologic conditions including porphyria cutanea tarda and lichen planus. Renal manifestations are also commonplace, with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis being identified in most patients.



Option Analysis

✅ Hepatitis C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human polyomavirus 2:
Incorrect: Human polyomavirus 2, also known as JC virus, is more commonly associated with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in patients with underlying HIV. This disease will present with neurologic symptoms and non-enhancing areas of demyelination on MRI.
❌ Human T-cell leukemia virus:
Incorrect: Human T-cell leukemia virus is associated with diffuse large T-cell lymphoma. While also common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use, this virus is more commonly found in patients from Japan, the Caribbean and west Africa. Patients will develop hypercalcemia and lytic bone lesions.
❌ Helicobacter pylori:
Incorrect: MALT lymphoma is more common in patients with underlying H. pylori infection. This disease will more commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms including postprandial pain or vomiting. It is not associated with the development of lichen planus.
❌ Epstein-Barr virus:
Incorrect: The Epstein-Barr virus is more commonly associated with Burkitt lymphoma, which histologically demonstrates a “starry sky” appearance. Additionally, Burkitt lymphoma is more commonly seen in younger patients as a rapidly enlarging mandibular mass (endemic variant) or abdominal mass (non-endemic/sporadic variant).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with several days of malaise, nausea, and vomiting. He recently returned from a trip to Thailand one week ago where he was staying in crowded hostels and eating seafood from local vendors. He reports a new sexual partner while abroad, and they did not use protection. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications daily. He smokes 3-4 cigarettes per day, although he reports he has not felt like smoking since onset of symptoms. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


Which of the following describes the mechanism of transmission resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after recent travel to Thailand with associated malaise, jaundice, nausea and vomiting. The evaluation is notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via fecal-oral transmission.  

Hepatitis A is an RNA picornavirus that is transmitted via contaminated food or water—often raw oysters or crab meat—and is the most common form of acute hepatitis. At-risk individuals include those who travel frequently and daycare workers. After inoculation, symptoms develop within anywhere from one week to thirty days and include malaise, fevers, jaundice, nausea, vomiting and right upper quadrant pain. For unknown reasons, patients with hepatitis A also develop an aversion to smoking tobacco products.  

Hepatitis A carries an excellent prognosis, with most patients only requiring supportive care at home. In contrast to other hepatitis viruses, hepatitis A does not carry an increased risk of developing cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma and does not have a carrier state. Patients that test positive for anti-HAV (IgM) are said to have active infection, while anti-HAV (IgG) indicates prior infection or immunity.

Option Analysis

✅ Fecal-oral:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and hepatitis C can be transmitted through unprotected sexual intercourse, although they are more commonly transmitted via contaminated blood or blood products. This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via a different mode of transmission.
❌ Intravenous contamination:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B, C, and D can be transmitted through contaminated needles, accidental needlestick exposures, or contact with contaminated blood. This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibodies, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via a different mode of transmission.  
❌ Respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A. Hepatitis viruses are not transmitted through respiratory secretions.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibodies, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A; however, none of the hepatitis viruses are transmitted through vectors such as mosquitos.
